If a violation of this article has not been personally witnessed by the chief of police or his authorized representative, a subpoena shall be issued to the person making the complaint, to appear on the day and time set for trial, then and there to testify on behalf of the city. (b) Impoundment. If the owner, possessor, or custodian of any dog or animal is not known and such dog or animal is upon the public streets, alleys, sidewalks, school grounds, or other public places or premises, or the property of another without the property owner's permission, as prohibited by this article, upon complaint made to, or information made known to, the police department, it shall be the duty of the chief of police or his authorized representative to take possession of such dog or animal and impound it in a facility designated by the city manager for the detention of animals. To the extent possible, the city manager shall designate that such impoundments shall be at the animal control center of the county, and such impoundments shall be regulated by such ordinances of the county board of commissioners as are enacted to regulate impoundments made by the county. (c) Authority of county animal control officers to impound. In the enforcement of the provisions of this article, all animal control officers employed as such by the county are hereby authorized when they witness, while on duty, violation of the provisions of this article within the corporate limits of the city, to cause summons to be issued requiring the owner, possessor or custodian of such dog or animal to appear before the municipal judge of the city on a day and time certain, then and there to stand trial for the violation of this article. If the owner, possessor, or custodian of any dog or animal is not known and such dog or animal is upon the public streets, alleys, sidewalks, school grounds, or other public places or premises, or the property of another without the property owner's permission, as prohibited by this article, to take possession of such dog or animal and impound it in a facility designated as stated in subsection (b) of this article, and such animal control officers of the county are specifically deputized as animal control officers of the city for the purposes described in this section. (Code 1967, § 5-25) Sec. 14-37. - Notice to owners of impounded animals. Notices to owners of any animal impounded at the county animal control center shall be given as prescribed by the ordinances of the county for the giving of notice for any animal impounded by the county. (Code 1967, § 5-26) Sec. 14-38. - Vaccinations for rabies and inoculation tags required for dogs and cats. All dogs and cats in the incorporated limits of the city shall be inoculated for the prevention of rabies by a licensed veterinarian. Evidence of this inoculation in the form of a rabies inoculation tag shall be worn by the dog and cat at all times. (Code 1967, § 5-27; Ord. No. O-99-19, § 7, 12-20-99) Sec. 14-39. - Guard dogs. It shall be the duty of each owner, tenant, or custodian of property upon or within which a guard dog is located to conspicuously and prominently post the following notice on the outside of the property: WARNING GUARD DOG in either red or black letters upon a white background, large enough to be easily read at a distance of 25 feet. In the case of a building, such notice shall be conspicuously posted on or about each and every entrance and exit. In the case of a general enclosure in which a guard dog is located, such notices shall be conspicuously posted upon such enclosure at a distance not greater than 50 feet apart as well as upon each and every entrance and exit through the enclosure. In the case of apartments, condominiums, or businesses located within a larger building where the guard dog is located within the apartment, condominium, or building solely, such notice shall be conspicuously posted on or about each and every entrance and exit. Failure to comply with this section shall be unlawful and shall be punishable as provided in section 1-12. (Code 1967, § 5-28) Sec. 14-39.1. - Dangerous animals. (a) If a law enforcement or codes enforcement agent of the city has probable cause to believe that a dangerous animal is being harbored in violation of this chapter, such agent may do one of the following: (1) Order the violation immediately corrected and cite the owner or keeper to appear in court for the violation. (2) If the violation cannot be immediately corrected and the animal is posing an immediate, serious threat to human beings or other domesticated animals, the animal may be seized and impounded, in which case the owner or keeper will be cited to appear in court for the violation. At the owner's request and expense, such impoundment may be at a veterinarian or licensed kennel of the owner's choosing. If the court rules that the animal is not dangerous, it will be released to the owner. If the court rules that it is dangerous, the animal will be released to the owner after payment of any fees and penalties and upon presentation of proof that the animal will now be kept restrained or confined as specified in section 14-33. (b) If the owner or keeper of an alleged dangerous animal impounded for violation of this chapter presents proof that the animal will now be kept in compliance with this chapter, the animal will be released upon payment of any fees and penalties due. (c) Notwithstanding any specific provision to the contrary, if an owner or keeper of dangerous animal fails to provide proof that the animal will be restrained or confined within compliance with the provisions of section 14-33; or, fails to reclaim it after impoundment; or, fails to keep the dangerous animal restrained or confined within compliance with the provisions of section 14-33; then section 5-6(c) and/or (d) of the DeKalb County Code of Ordinances will apply. (Ord. No. O-99-19, § 11, 12-20-99) Sec. 14-40. - Abandonment or abuse of animals. It shall be unlawful for anyone to knowingly abandon or abuse any domesticated animal within the city. Each person who does abandon or abuse knowingly, or willingly permits such abandonment or abuse, or aids in the abandonment or abuse of any domesticated animal, shall be in violation of the law and shall be punishable as provided in section 1-12. (Code 1967, § 5-29; Ord. No. O-99-19, § 8, 12-20-99) Sec. 14-41. - Fee schedule. In the reclaiming of animals from the county animal control center, such fees shall prevail as are established by the county board of commissioners. (Code 1967, § 5-30) Sec. 14-42. - Wild animals—Permit required. No person shall have, keep, or maintain any wild, exotic, dangerous, or nondomestic animal or reptile without first applying to and receiving from the police department a permit to do so. The charge for this permit shall be as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges. (Code 1967, § 5-31) Sec. 14-43. - Same—Authority of police department. The police department is hereby invested with the authority to issue permits to any person for the keeping or maintaining of any wild, exotic, dangerous, or nondomestic animal or reptile when, in the opinion of the police chief, any such animal or reptile may be kept or maintained without menacing the safety of any person or property; provided, however, that the police department may require any such animal or reptile to be properly caged or secured or may make additional rules or regulations regarding the keeping or maintaining of any such animal or reptile, and may revoke any such permit for any violation of any of the provisions of this article or of any of the rules and regulations of the police department, or when, in the opinion of the police chief, the safety of any person or property is menaced by the keeping of any such animal or reptile. (Code 1967, § 5-32)

div.head: Chapter 22 - BUSINESSES[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Alcoholic beverages, ch. 6; amusements and entertainments, ch. 10; health and sanitation, ch. 54; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 86; taxation, ch. 94; vehicles for hire, ch. 102; zoning, pt. IV. UDO. State Law reference— Local taxes and fees, Ga. Const. art. IX, § IV, ¶ I.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 22-1. - Rummage, garage, carport and similar sales; permit required. It shall be unlawful for any person to hold a rummage, garage, carport, outdoor auction of personal property, or similar sales within the city without first obtaining from the city manager, or his designated representative, a permit for the holding of such sale at some designated place which shall be approved by the city manager. Such sales, when held under such permit, shall be governed by such rules and regulations as may be promulgated by the city manager. (Code 1967, § 16-29) Sec. 22-2. - Peddling or soliciting; permit required. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person to go from residence to residence and offer for sale, solicit orders for, or sell any merchandise, or to solicit to perform services, or to engage in charitable solicitation within the city without first obtaining a permit to do so from the City of Decatur. (b) The chief of police, or his/her designee, shall cause each person requesting such a permit to be photographed and fingerprinted and shall take such other steps as are necessary to ensure proper identification of the person. The chief of police shall issue a permit to any person who is not disqualified pursuant to subsection (c). (c) The chief of police shall deny a permit to any person who has been convicted, been on probation, parole, or been imprisoned for the violation of any of the following offenses of the State of Georgia, of any other state, or of the United States within a period of five years immediately prior to the date of request for a permit: homicide; rape; aggravated battery; burglary; aggravated assault; kidnapping; robbery; child molestation; criminal solicitation to commit any of these listed offenses; attempts to commit any of these offenses; any crime of violence or theft; sale or distribution of controlled substances; or violation of any other state law or local government ordinance involving improper residential solicitation activities. (d) A fee as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges shall be charged for each permit, except that the permit fee shall be waived for persons officially representing charitable organizations, as that term is defined by O.C.G.A. § 43-17-2. (e) If a permit is issued, it shall be on the person engaged in going from residence to residence and offering for sale, soliciting orders for, or selling merchandise, or soliciting to perform services, or in making charitable solicitations. (f) Permits issued pursuant to subsection (b) shall be valid from 9:00 a.m. until 8:00 p.m. and will expire 90 days after date of issuance. (Code 1967, § 16-24; Ord. No. O-97-12, 4-7-97; Ord. No. O-08-10, 8-4-08) State Law reference— Peddlers and itinerant traders, O.C.G.A. § 43-32-1 et seq. Secs. 22-3, 22-4. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - OCCUPATION TAXES[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- Editor's note— Ord. No. O-95-16, adopted Dec. 20, 1995, repealed § 22-31, which comprised the substantive provisions of this art. II, occupation taxes and regulatory fees, provisions saved from repeal, and enacted similar new provisions as herein set out. State Law reference— Business and occupation taxes, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-5 et seq.
Sec. 22-5. - Occupation tax required; business dealings in city. For the year 1996 and succeeding years thereafter, each person engaged in any business, trade, profession, or occupation in the city, whether with a location in the city or in the case of an out-of-state business with no location in Georgia exerting substantial efforts within the state pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-13-7, shall pay an occupation tax for such business, trade, profession, or occupation; which tax and any applicable registration shall be displayed in a conspicuous place in the place of business, if the taxpayer has a permanent business location in the city. If the taxpayer has no permanent business location in the city, such business tax registration shall be shown to the city clerk or his/her designees or to any police officer or codes enforcement officer of the city upon request. (Ord. No. O-95-16, 12-20-95) Sec. 22-6. - Construction of terms; definitions. (a) Generally. Wherever the term Decatur is used herein, such term shall be construed to mean the City of Decatur, Georgia; wherever the term city is used herein, it shall be construed to mean the City of Decatur, Georgia. (b) Specific terms. As used in this article, the following terms shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them as follows: Administrative fee means a component of an occupation tax which approximates the reasonable cost of handling and processing the occupation tax. City clerk means the appointed city clerk of the City of Decatur, Georgia, or his/her designee. Dominant line means the type of business, within a multiple-line business, that the greatest amount of income is derived from. Location or office means a fixed place located within the city from which a person conducts business, but shall not include a work site located in the city for less than four months in any calendar year for the purpose of serving a single customer or project. Occupation tax certificate means a document issued by the city acknowledging payment of the occupation tax and administrative fee. Occupation tax means a tax levied on persons, partnerships, corporations, or other entities for engaging in an occupation, profession, or business for revenue raising purposes. Person shall be held to include sole proprietors, corporations, partnerships, nonprofits, or any other form of business organization. Practitioner of profession or occupation is one who, by state law requires state licensure regulating such profession or occupation. Practitioners of professions are: (1) Lawyers. (2) Physicians licensed under O.C.G.A. title 43, chapter 34. (3) Osteopaths licensed under O.C.G.A. title 43, chapter 34. (4) Chiropractors. (5) Podiatrists. (6) Dentists. (7) Optometrists. (8) Psychologists. (9) Veterinarians. (10) Landscape architects. (11) Land surveyors. (12) Practitioners of physiotherapy. (13) Public accountants. (14) Embalmers. (15) Funeral directors. (16) Civil, mechanical, hydraulic, or electrical engineers. (17) Architects. (18) Marriage and family therapists, social workers, and professional counselors. Practitioners of professions and occupations shall not include a practitioner who is an employee of a business, if the business pays an occupation tax. Regulatory fee means payments, whether designated as license fees, permit fees, or by another name, which are required by a local government as an exercise of its police power and as a part of or an aid to regulation of an occupation, profession, or business. A regulatory fee may not include an administrative fee. Development impact fees as defined by O.C.G.A. § 36-71-2, paragraph 8 or other costs or conditions of zoning or land development are not regulatory fees for the purposes of this article. (Ord. No. O-95-16, 12-20-95) Sec. 22-7. - Administrative and regulatory fee structure. (a) A nonprorated, nonrefundable administrative fee of $25.00 shall be required on all business and occupation tax accounts for the initial startup, renewal, or reopening of those accounts. (b) A regulatory fee will be imposed as provided under O.C.G.A. § 48-13-9 on those applicable businesses. A regulatory fee may not include an administrative fee. (c) The regulatory fee schedule shall be as described elsewhere in the Decatur City Code. (d) The administrative fee of $25.00 shall be waived for certificate renewals paid within 30 days of invoicing. (Ord. No. O-95-16, 12-20-95; Ord. No. O-15-12, § I, 10-5-15) Sec. 22-8. - Occupation tax levied; restrictions. (a) An occupation tax shall be levied upon those businesses and practitioners of professions and occupations with one or more locations or offices in the corporate limits of the city and/or upon the applicable out-of-state businesses with no location or office in the state pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-13-7, based on the dominant line of business, based upon the following criteria: (1) Profitability ratio for the type of business, profession, or occupation as measured by nationwide averages derived from statistics, classifications, or other information published by the U.S. Internal Revenue Service, or successor agencies of the United States. The city manager or his or her designee shall review the assignment of businesses to profitability classes on an annual basis and administratively reassign businesses as necessary to the accurate profitability class in accordance with the most recent such nationwide averages. A copy of the annual administrative assignment of businesses to profitability classes shall be kept on file in the office of the city clerk. (2) The particular type of business, profession, or occupation as classified by the North American Industrial Classification System (NAICS). A copy of the NAICS manual shall be kept on file in the office of the city clerk. (b) Occupation tax schedule: Profitability ratios: The tax rate for each business, trade, profession, or occupation is determined by ranking profitability ratios according to federal statistics as follows:
Class 1 includes businesses with the sixteenth highest profitability ratio and all lower profitability ratios. Class 2 includes businesses with the thirteenth, fourteenth, and fifteenth highest profitability ratios. Class 3 includes businesses with the tenth, eleventh, and twelfth highest profitability ratios. Class 4 includes businesses with the seventh, eighth, and ninth highest profitability ratios. Class 5 includes businesses with the fourth, fifth, and sixth highest profitability ratios. Class 6 includes businesses with the first, second, and third highest profitability ratios. (c) (1) No business or practitioner shall be required to pay more than one occupation tax for each of its locations. (2) No occupation tax shall be required from those real estate brokers, real estate agents, or real estate companies whose offices are located outside the jurisdiction and who sell property inside the jurisdiction. (Ord. No. O-95-16, 12-20-95; Ord. No. O-15-12, §§ II, III, 10-5-15) Sec. 22-9. - Paying occupation tax of business with no location in state. Registration and assessment of an occupation tax is hereby imposed on those businesses and practitioners of professions with no location or office in the state if the business's largest dollar volume of business in the state is in the city and the business or practitioner: (1) Has one or more employees or agents who exert substantial efforts within the jurisdiction of the city for the purpose of soliciting business or serving customers or clients; or (2) Owns personal or real property which generates income and which is located within the jurisdiction of the city and which generates income or is used to generate income. (Ord. No. O-95-16, 12-20-95) Sec. 22-10. - Each line of business to be identified. The registration of each business operated in the local government's jurisdiction shall identify the line or lines of business that the business conducts. No business shall conduct any line of business without first having that line of business registered with the city clerk's office and that line of business being noted by the city clerk's office upon the occupation tax certificate which is to be displayed by the business owner. (Ord. No. O-95-16, 12-20-95) Sec. 22-11. - Number of businesses considered to be operating in city. Where a person conducts business at more than one fixed location, each location or place shall be considered a separate business for the purpose of occupation taxes, administrative fees, and regulatory fees. (Ord. No. O-95-16, 12-20-95) Sec. 22-12. - Professionals as classified in state law. Practitioners of professions as described in O.C.G.A. § 48-13-9(c)(1) through (18) shall elect as their entire occupation tax one of the following: (1) The occupation tax based on profitability ratio; (2) A fee of $400.00 per practitioner who is licensed to provide the service, such tax to be paid at the practitioner's office or location; provided, however, that a practitioner paying according to this paragraph shall not be required to provide information to the local government relating to the gross receipts of the business or practitioner. The per-practitioner fee applies to each person in the business who qualifies as a practitioner under the state's regulatory guidelines and framework; (3) This election is to be made on an annual basis and must be done on or before January 31, 1996. Such election shall be changed for subsequent calendar years only by a written request filed by the professional on or before January 31 of the year in which the election is to be changed. (Ord. No. O-95-16, 12-20-95) Sec. 22-13. - Practitioners exclusively practicing for a government. Any practitioner whose office is maintained by and who is employed in practice exclusively by the United States, the state, a municipality or county of the state, instrumentalities of the United States, the state, or a municipality or county of the state shall not be required to obtain a license or pay an occupation tax for that practice. (Ord. No. O-95-16, 12-20-95) Sec. 22-14. - Purpose and scope of tax. The occupation tax levied herein is for revenue purposes only and is not for regulatory purposes, nor is the payment of the tax made a condition precedent to the practice of any such profession, trade, or calling. The occupation tax only applies to those businesses and occupations which are covered by the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 48-13-5 to 48-13-26. All other applicable businesses and occupations are taxed by the local government pursuant to the pertinent general and/or local law and ordinance. (Ord. No. O-95-16, 12-20-95) Sec. 22-15. - When tax due and payable; effect of transacting business when tax or fee delinquent. (a) Except for lawyers, each such occupation tax or administrative fee, as applicable, shall be for the calendar year 1996 and succeeding calendar years thereafter unless otherwise specifically provided. Any occupation tax or administrative fee on businesses continuing from the preceding year shall be due and payable annually to the city by January 31 of each year and shall, if not paid by April 30 of each year, be subject to a ten percent penalty of the amount of tax or fees due and interest at the rate of one percent per month or any portion thereof. Any occupation tax or administrative fee for lawyers shall be payable pursuant to the provisions of section 22-26. (b) On any new profession, trade or calling begun in the city in 1996 or succeeding years thereafter, except for the practice of law, the occupation tax shall be delinquent if not paid immediately upon beginning business and a penalty of ten percent and interest at the rate of one percent per month or any portion thereof shall be imposed if not paid within 90 days after commencing business. (c) The occupation tax certificate herein provided for shall be issued by the city. (d) In addition to the above remedies, the city may proceed to collect in the same manner as provided by law for tax executions. (Ord. No. O-95-16, 12-20-95; Ord. No. O-97-13, 4-7-97; Ord. No. O-03-10, §§ II—IV, 8-19-03; Ord. No. O-15-12, §§ IV—VIII, 10-5-15) Sec. 22-16. - Proration of tax. If a person commences business in the city on or after July 1 in any calendar year, the occupation tax for the remaining portion of the year shall be 50 percent of the tax imposed for the entire year. The administrative fee shall not be reduced. This provision is not intended to benefit delinquent persons who did operate a business prior to July 1 of the calendar year. (Ord. No. O-95-16, 12-20-95) Sec. 22-17. - Exemption on grounds that business is operated for charitable purpose. No business on which an occupation tax, regulatory fee, or administrative fee is levied by this article shall be exempt from such fee or tax on the ground that such business is operated for a charitable purpose, unless 100 percent or more of the entire proceeds from such business are devoted to such purpose; except that places of worship and schools shall be exempt. (Ord. No. O-95-16, 12-20-95) Sec. 22-18. - Evidence of state registration required if applicable. Each person who is required to be licensed by the secretary of state pursuant to O.C.G.A. title 43, excluding aviation and aeronautical engineers, shall provide evidence of proper and current state licensure before the city occupation tax certificate and/or regulatory fee certificate may be issued. (Ord. No. O-95-16, 12-20-95; Ord. No. O-97-13, 4-7-97; Ord. No. O-15-12, § VIII, 10-5-15) Sec. 22-19. - Evidence of qualification required if applicable. Any business required to obtain health permits, bonds, certificates of qualification, certificates of competency, or any other regulatory matter shall first, before the issuance of a city occupation tax certificate or regulatory fee certificate, show evidence that such requirements have been met. (Ord. No. O-95-16, 12-20-95) Sec. 22-20. - Liability of officers and agents; registration required; failure to obtain. All persons subject to the occupation tax levy pursuant to this article shall be required to obtain the necessary city occupation tax certificate and/or regulatory fee certificate for such business as described in this article, and in default thereof the officer or agent soliciting for or representing such persons shall be subject to the same penalty as other persons who fail to obtain a city occupation tax certificate and/or regulatory fee certificate. Every person commencing business in the city after January 1 of each year shall likewise obtain the city occupation tax certificate and/or regulatory fee certificate herein provided for upon or before commencing the same. (Ord. No. O-95-16, 12-20-95; Ord. No. O-97-13, 4-7-97) Sec. 22-21. - When occupation tax due and payable. (a) Each such occupation tax shall be for the calendar year in which the occupation tax certificate was obtained unless otherwise specifically provided. Every person commencing business in the city after January 1 of each year shall obtain the occupation tax certificate required upon or before commencing such business. (b) The occupation tax certificate herein provided for shall be issued by the city clerk. (Ord. No. O-95-16, 12-20-95; Ord. No. O-97-13, 4-7-97) Secs. 22-22, 22-23. - Reserved. Editor's note— Ord. No. O-97-13, adopted Apr. 7, 1997, repealed §§ 22-22 and 22-23, which pertained to penalty of ordinance violation and city clerk, subpoena and arrest powers, respectively, and derived from Ord. No. O-95-16, adopted Dec. 20, 1995. Sec. 22-24. - Businesses not covered by this article. (a) The following businesses are not covered by the provisions of this article but may be assessed an occupation tax or other type of tax pursuant to the provisions of other general laws of the state or by local law: (1) Those businesses regulated by the Georgia Public Service Commission. (2) Those electrical service businesses organized under O.C.G.A. title 46, chapter 3. (3) Any farm operation for the production from or on the land of agricultural products, but not including agribusiness. (4) Nonprofit agricultural product cooperative marketing associations governed by O.C.G.A. § 2-10-105. (5) Insurance companies governed by O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8 et seq. (6) Motor common carriers governed by O.C.G.A. § 46-7-15. (7) Those businesses governed by O.C.G.A. § 48-5-355. (Businesses that purchase carload lots of guano, meats, meal, flour, bran, cottonseed, or cottonseed meal and hulls.) (8) Agricultural products and livestock raised in the state governed by O.C.G.A. § 48-5-356. (9) Depository financial institutions governed by O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93. (10) Any business where the levy of such occupation tax is prohibited by the laws of the state or the United States. (b) The exemptions and limitations contained in this article shall not be construed to repeal or otherwise affect in any way franchise fees, business taxes, or other fees or taxes otherwise permitted by law. (Ord. No. O-95-16, 12-20-95) Sec. 22-25. - More than one place or line of business. Where a business is operated at more than one place or where the business includes more than one line, said business shall be required to obtain the necessary registration for each location and line and pay an occupation tax in accordance with the prevailing taxing method and tax rate for the dominant line of business. (Ord. No. O-95-16, 12-20-95) Sec. 22-26. - Exemption of lawyers from registration and certificate requirements; when occupation tax due and payable for lawyers. (a) Lawyers are expressly exempted from the registration and occupation tax certificate requirements, including posting of the certificate, of this article. Such an exemption shall not affect the occupation tax payment requirement for lawyers under this article. (b) Any occupation tax or administrative fee for lawyers shall be due and payable annually to the city by December 31 of each year and shall, if not paid by March 31 of the following year, be subject to a ten percent penalty of the amount of tax or fees due and interest at the rate of one percent per month. Such occupation tax or administrative fee for lawyers shall be for the calendar year concluding on December 31. (Ord. No. O-03-10, § I, 8-19-03; Ord. No. O-15-12, §§ IX, X, 10-5-15) Sec. 22-27. - Lien taken for delinquent occupation tax. In addition to the other remedies herein provided for the collection of the occupation tax herein levied, the city clerk's office of the city, upon any tax or installment of such tax becoming delinquent and remaining unpaid, shall issue execution for the correct amount of such tax against the persons, partnership, or corporation liable for the tax, which execution shall bear interest at the rate of 18 percent per annum from the date when such tax or installment becomes delinquent, and the lien shall cover the property (in the city) of the person, partnership, or corporation liable for the tax, all as provided by the laws, ordinances, and charter of the city and the laws of the state. The lien of such occupation tax shall become fixed on and date from the time when such tax or any installment thereof becomes delinquent. The execution shall be levied by the city clerk or marshal of the city upon the property of the defendant located in the jurisdiction, and sufficient property shall be advertised and sold to pay the amount of the execution, with interest and costs. All other proceedings in relation thereto shall be had as is provided by the laws, ordinances, and charter of the city and the laws of the state, and the defendant in the execution shall have rights of defense, by affidavit of illegality and otherwise, which are provided by the applicable laws in regard to tax executions. (Ord. No. O-95-16, 12-20-95; Ord. No. O-97-13, 4-7-97) Sec. 22-28. - Amendment, repeal of provision. This article shall be subject to amendment or repeal, in whole or in part, at any time, and no such amendment or repeal shall be construed to deny the right of the city commission to assess and collect any of the taxes or other charges prescribed. The amendment may increase or lower the amounts and tax rates of any occupation and may change the classification thereof. The payment of any occupation tax provided for shall not be construed as prohibiting the levy or collection by the jurisdiction of additional occupation taxes upon the same person, property, or business. (Ord. No. O-95-16, 12-20-95) Sec. 22-29. - Applications of provisions to prior ordinance. This article does not repeal or affect the force of any part of any ordinance heretofore passed where taxes levied under such prior ordinance have not been paid in full. So much and such parts of ordinances heretofore and hereinafter passed as provided for the issuing and enforcing of execution for any tax or assessment required by such ordinances, or that imposed civil penalties for the nonpayment of such tax, or for failure to pay regulatory fees provided for in such ordinance or ordinances, or failure to comply with any other provisions hereof, shall continue and remain in force until such tax, regulatory fee, or assessment shall be fully paid. (Ord. No. O-95-16, 12-20-95; Ord. No. O-97-13, 4-7-97) Sec. 22-30. - Enforcement of provisions. (a) It is hereby made the duty of city officers designated by the city manager to see that the provisions of this article relating to occupation taxes are observed. City police officers are hereby authorized to issue citations for violations of this article. Each citation shall state the specific provision allegedly violated. It is made the further duty of such designated officers to inspect all occupation tax certificates issued by the city as often as in their judgment it may seem necessary to determine whether the occupation tax certificate held is proper for the business sought to be transacted hereunder. (b) Except for lawyers, a person or business violating any provisions of this article shall, upon order of the municipal court, be subject to a civil penalty in an amount not to exceed $500.00. Such civil penalty may be enforced by the contempt power of the municipal court. (c) Lawyers who fail to pay the occupation tax by the payment deadline may be reported by the city to the State Bar of Georgia. (Ord. No. O-95-16, 12-20-95; Ord. No. O-97-13, 4-7-97; Ord. No. O-15-12, §§ XI, XII, 10-5-15) Sec. 22-31. - Provisions to remain in full force and effect until changed by governing body. This article shall remain in full force and effect until changed by amendment adopted by the city commission. All provisions hereto relating to any form of tax herein levied shall remain in full force and effect until such taxes have been paid in full. (Ord. No. O-95-16, 12-20-95) Sec. 22-32. - Public hearing requirements. (a) After January 1, 1996, the city commission shall conduct at least one public hearing before adopting any ordinance or resolution which will increase the rate of occupation tax as set forth in this article. (b) In any year when revenue from occupation taxes is greater than revenue from occupation taxes for the preceding year for the city, the city commission shall hold one or more public hearings as a part of the process of determining how to use the additional revenue. (Ord. No. O-95-16, 12-20-95) Sec. 22-33. - Option to establish exemption or reduction in occupation tax. The city commission may by subsequent ordinance or resolution provide for an exemption or reduction in occupation tax to one or more types of businesses or practitioners of occupations or professions as part of a written plan for economic development or attracting or encouraging selected types of businesses or practitioners of selected occupations or professions. Such exemptions or reductions in occupation tax shall not be arbitrary or capricious, and the reasons shall be set forth in a written economic development plan approved by the city commission. (Ord. No. O-95-16, 12-20-95) Sec. 22-34. - Peddlers. Any person in the city offering for sale merchandise in a door-to-door fashion, shall be deemed a peddler and every such peddler shall be required to pay an occupation tax, based on the dominant line of business as classified by the appropriate NAICS code. (Ord. No. O-95-16, 12-20-95; Ord. No. O-15-12, §§ XIII, XIV, 10-5-15) Sec. 22-35. - Stands. No occupation tax certificate, regulatory fee certificate, or clearance to operate shall be issued to any shoe shine, newsstand, popcorn, food/beverage vendor, or any other retail stand, where such stand or stands propose to locate on any street, sidewalk, alley, or public area of the city, unless written permission is granted by the city commission. (Ord. No. O-95-16, 12-20-95) Sec. 22-36. - Businesses not listed. Any person, firm, or corporation desiring to conduct any other business than those specified in the following schedule shall make application to the city manager or his or her designee, who shall determine the most appropriate NAICS code and amount of such tax based on profitability ratios, and shall instruct the Revenue Division as to the classification and amount of the tax. (Ord. No. O-95-16, 12-20-95; Ord. No. O-15-12, § XV, 10-5-15) Sec. 22-37. - Reduction in tax for persons with a business activity located in their principal residence. Other provisions of this chapter notwithstanding, a person required to obtain an occupation tax certificate for a business activity located in his/her primary residence with no more than one non-resident employed in the business activity for no more than ten hours per week shall pay the occupation tax normally required as specified in section 22-7 and section 22-8 for profitability ratio/tax class 1. No reduction in the administrative fee or regulatory fee(s) is intended for these persons. If these persons begin business operations prior to July 1 of the calendar year, they must pay the normal occupation tax. If these persons begin business operations after July 1 of the calendar year, and have not operated any portion of their business prior to July 1, then they shall pay one-half of the normal occupation tax. (Ord. No. O-95-16, 12-20-95; Ord. No. O-01-05, 3-5-01) Sec. 22-38. - Denial. (a) The city manager or his/her designee shall be authorized to deny an application for an occupation tax certificate, for any of the following reasons: (1) The applicant fails to provide evidence required by section 2-18. (2) The applicant furnishes fraudulent or untruthful information or omits required information in the application for an occupation tax certificate. (3) The applicant is not a citizen of the United States or lawfully present in the United States, as evidenced by an affidavit complying with O.C.G.A. § 50-36-1. (b) The city manager or his or her designee shall give written notification to the applicant of such denial, including a specification of the reasons for denial. (c) An applicant may appeal a denial through the appeals procedure identified in section 22-39. (d) An applicant shall not furnish fraudulent or untruthful information in the application. (Ord. No. O-15-12, § XVI, 10-5-15) Sec. 22-39. - Procedure for appeals. Any person taxed under this article shall have the right to appeal the tax classification to the city commission, provided however that the appeal be in writing stating the grounds for the appeal and provided that the petition of appeal be first presented to the city manager. (Ord. No. O-95-16, 12-20-95) Sec. 22-40. - Conflicts between specific and general provisions. Where there is an apparent conflict in this article between specific and general provisions, it is the intention hereof that the specific shall control. (Ord. No. O-95-16, 12-20-95) Sec. 22-41. - Alteration of certificates. The holder of an occupation tax certificate shall not alter or modify the information contained on any occupation tax certificate issued by the city. (Ord. No. O-15-12, § XVII, 10-5-15) Secs. 22-42—22-45. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - BAIL BONDS AND BAIL BONDING COMPANIES[3]

Sec. 22-46. - Business license required. The business of arranging, posting and acting as surety on bonds for accused in any city ordinance violation coming within the jurisdiction of the city and any person or other entity desiring to conduct such business within the city limits is required, prior to the conducting of such business, to obtain a business license from the city. Such license shall be granted in accordance with the terms and conditions as set forth in this article, and may be revoked by the city upon violation of any of the terms and conditions of this article. (Code 1967, § 5½-1) Sec. 22-47. - License fee; posting of license. The annual license fee for the conduct of a bonding business, as referred to in section 22-46, shall be as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges. The license shall be posted in a conspicuous place at the office of the bonding company, visible to any individual lawfully on the premises. (Code 1967, § 5½-2) Sec. 22-48. - Posting of certificate of deposit prerequisite to issuance of license. Any bonding company, prior to the conduct of any business in the city, shall post, or cause to be posted, with the city clerk a certificate of deposit in an amount set forth in the schedule of fees and charges. The amount required to be posted may, in the sole discretion of the city commission, be increased or decreased, but notice of any increase shall only be effective after notice to any licensed bonding company and by appropriate amendment to this article. The certificate of deposit shall be endorsed by the bonding company to the city, and shall be held by the city subject to the terms and conditions as are set forth in this article. The posting of such certificate of deposit shall be a condition precedent to the issuance of any business license to any bonding company and shall be in such form as may be required by the city. (Code 1967, § 5½-3) Sec. 22-49. - Form of bond; bonding schedule. All bonds posted by any bonding company as surety for accused shall be on forms acceptable to the city and shall be in accordance with the current bonding schedule of the city as may be set by the municipal court from time to time or in accordance with bonds as may be set by the municipal court in any particular case, and further shall be in accordance with any future bond schedules which may be promulgated at any time hereafter. (Code 1967, § 5½-4) Sec. 22-50. - Bonds to be made returnable to appearance date in municipal court. All bonds shall be made returnable to the appearance date in the municipal court for the city. (Code 1967, § 5½-5) Sec. 22-51. - Forfeiture of bond. Should any individual accused of violating any of the ordinances or laws referred to in the bonding schedule, as referred to in section 22-49, and for whom a bonding company has acted as surety or posted bond, fail to appear at his appearance date, including continuances, then the bond of that individual failing to appear shall be declared forfeited, and the bonding company, which acted as surety thereon, shall have a period of 28 days from the appearance date to deliver the individual up before the municipal court. If after the expiration of 28 days the individual has not been brought before the municipal court, any subsequent continuances included, then the bonding company which has acted as surety on that individual's bond shall pay to the city the value of the cash bond as reflected in the bond schedules referred to in section 22-49. At no time shall any monies paid by the bonding company to the city, pursuant to the provisions of this article, be returnable to the bonding company by the city. (Code 1967, § 5½-6) Sec. 22-52. - Continuance of bond. If any individual shall be bound over by the municipal court to a higher court, then, it shall be within the sole discretion of the municipal court whether to continue the bond for that individual and to make the bond returnable to any required appearance in any higher court to which the individual is bound if the latter procedure is permissible. (Code 1967, § 5½-7) Sec. 22-53. - Nonpayment of forfeited bonds. The certificate of deposit referred to in section 22-48, which each bonding company is required to post, shall be a fund from which the city may, at its sole election, collect any forfeited bonds which are not promptly paid by the bonding company in accordance with the provisions of this article. This section shall in no way limit the liability of the bonding company such amount as may be required in the schedule of fees and charges, and each bonding company shall be liable directly to the city for any and all amounts due the city by virtue of forfeited bonds, whether or not the sums exceed the amount set forth in the schedule of fees and charges. In the event of nonpayment of any forfeited bond, the city may, at its election, sell or cash the certificate of deposit, and deduct from the proceeds thereof any and all amounts due the city by the bonding company for forfeited bonds, together with all costs incurred by the city in the sale or negotiation of the certificate of deposit, and the balance remaining, if any, shall be delivered to the bonding company. The business license for the bonding company shall, upon default, be immediately revoked. (Code 1967, § 5½-8) Sec. 22-54. - Settlement of case prior to appearance date. If any case is settled prior to the designated appearance date either by a plea by the accused or by the payment of a fine, if allowed, for the particular offense, or both, the bonding company which acted as surety on that individual's bond shall be relieved of all further liability. It shall be the sole responsibility of the bonding company to determine whether or not a case has been disposed of prior to the appearance date. (Code 1967, § 5½-10) Sec. 22-55. - Revocation of license. Any violation of any section of this article or regulation of the city, or any violation of any other statute, law or resolution by any bonding company shall be grounds for the revocation of the business license of the offending company. In the event of any such revocation, the bonding company shall immediately cease to act as surety on any bonds after the date of revocation, but shall remain liable and bound to the city for any bonds for which it is surety prior to such revocation. The city commission shall have the power to revoke any business license for any bonding company, after notice to the offending bonding company and a hearing at any scheduled commission meeting. (Code 1967, § 5½-11) Sec. 22-56. - License to be obtained prior to commencing business; date fee due and payable. The license shall be procured before any bonding company commences business. The annual license fee shall be payable on or before February 1 of each year thereafter, except that any bonding company obtaining a license prior to January 1, 1980, may function by paying for their license for the year 1980. (Code 1967, § 5½-13) Secs. 22-57—22-75. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - INSURANCE COMPANIES[4]

No. O-94-16, § 12½-41, 12-19-94) Sec. 22-77. - Additional license fees for insurers insuring certain risks at additional business locations. (Ord. No. O-94-16, § 12½-43, 12-19-94) Sec. 22-79. - Gross premiums tax imposed on life insurers. There is hereby levied for the year 1995 and for each year thereafter an annual tax based solely upon gross direct premiums upon each insurer writing life, accident and sickness insurance within the state in an amount equal to one percent of the gross direct premiums received during the preceding calendar year in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8.1. There is hereby levied for the year 1995 and for each year thereafter an annual tax based solely upon gross direct premiums upon each insurer, other than an insurer transacting business in the class of insurance designated in O.C.G.A. § 33-3-5(1), doing business within the state in an amount equal to 2½ percent of the gross direct premiums received during the preceding calendar year in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 33-8-8.2. The term "gross direct premiums," as used in this section, shall mean gross direct premiums as used in O.C.G.A. § 33-8-4. The premium tax levied by this section is in addition to the license fees imposed by other sections of this article. (Ord. No. O-94-16, § 12½-45, 12-19-94) Sec. 22-81. - Due date for license fees. License fees imposed in other sections of this article shall be due and payable on January 1, 1995, and on the first day of each subsequent year. (Ord. No. O-94-16, § 12½-46, 12-19-94) Sec. 22-82. - Administrative provisions. The city clerk is hereby directed to forward a duly certified copy of this article to the state insurance commissioner within 45 days of its enactment. (Ord. No. O-94-16, § 12½-47, 12-19-94) Secs. 22-83—22-100. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - TELEPHONE COMPANIES[5]

Sec. 22-101. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Recurring local service revenues means: (1) Monthly charges for local exchange service, including: a. Charges for additional listings and joint users; b. The guarantee portion of the charge for semipublic pay station services; c. Charges for local message rate service, including mobile service local messages; and d. Subscriber station revenues from tele-typewriter exchange service. (2) Charges for Morse transmission, signaling, data transmission, remote metering and supervisory control, where both terminal points are within the city limits. (3) All charges for local private line services, except audio and video program transmission services, where both terminals of the private line are within the city limits. Nothing in this definition shall preclude the charging of a separate franchise fee for the transmission of audio or video programs to customers by CATV companies. Each telephone company operating in the city shall pay an occupational license tax in the amount of three percent of the recurring local service revenues received by such company from subscribers located within the city. Such occupational license tax shall be paid in quarterly installments, each of which shall be due on or before the last day of the second month following the end of each calendar quarter and shall be based on recurring local service revenues billed during such calendar quarter. The first payment under this article shall be based on revenues billed between the effective date of this article (January 1, 1974) and the end of the calendar quarter in which such effective date falls. Any amount of license tax previously paid and absorbed by a telephone company which is applicable to any period subsequent to the effective date of this article shall be credited against the amounts imposed in this article or by subsequent ordinance. Sec. 22-131. - License fee levied. (a) There is hereby levied an annual license fee upon the gross receipts generated by or credited to an office within the corporate limits of the city upon each national bank and banking association, federal savings and loan association, building and loan association, bank organized and chartered under the laws of the state, and corporations doing banking business within the city. Such license fee shall be based upon the amount of annual gross receipts and is hereby fixed at the following rate schedule: (1) Five-tenths percent of gross receipts on the first $3,000,000.00 of gross receipts; (2) One-tenth percent of gross receipts on the next $20,000,000.00 ($3,000,000.00 to $23,000,000.00) of gross receipts; (3) None upon the gross receipts in excess of $23,000,000.00. (b) The term "gross receipts" shall mean the gross receipts of the business from all earnings, fees, commissions, interest, rentals and all other income whatsoever arising from or growing out of the conduct of the business without any deduction whatsoever except sales and excise taxes. (Code 1967, § 12½-71) Sec. 22-132. - Administrative provisions. (a) Each such corporation to which this article applies, doing business within the city shall, on or before May 1 each year, file with the clerk of the city its estimate of gross receipts to be generated for that year. The license fees levied by this article based on such estimate are due and payable on June 1, 1975, and on June 1 of each succeeding year. Any such license fee based on such estimate not paid by July 1 for each respective year shall be delinquent, and further, on or before the following February 1 of each year, each such corporation or association doing business shall file its report under oath with the clerk of the city showing its actual aggregate gross receipts for the preceding calendar year. If such report reflects an estimated underpayment of the actual license fee payable under the provisions of this article, the amount of such underpayment shall be due and payable on February 1 each year and shall be delinquent if not paid by March 1 each year. If such report reflects an estimated overpayment of the actual license tax levied by this article, such overpayment shall be refunded by the city. All reports required to be filed under this article shall be confidential, and the information contained therein shall be solely for use of the officers of the city responsible for administering this article. (b) The clerk of the city shall be authorized to prepare and supply forms for the preparation and submission of reports of estimated gross receipts and reports of actual annual gross receipts. (Code 1967, § 12½-72) Sec. 22-133. - Determination of license fee for new business. If a business, as described and classified in this article, is commenced after May 1 of any license year that this article is in effect, it shall be the duty of any such new business to file with the clerk of the city, on or before commencing business, its estimate of gross receipts to be generated for that year and to pay on or before the date such business is commenced the license fee based upon such estimate, computed according to the rate specified in this article. Any such license fee based on such estimate not paid within 30 days from the date such business is commenced shall be delinquent, and further, on or before the following February 1, such corporation shall file its report under oath with the clerk of the city showing its actual aggregate gross receipts for such preceding partial calendar year. The provisions of section 22-132 with respect to underpayment or overpayment of estimated license fees shall also be applicable to such new business. (Code 1967, § 12½-73) Sec. 22-134. - Enforcement of article. The fees and taxes levied by this article may be enforced by execution in the same manner as other taxes of the city. A violation of this article shall be grounds for refusing or revoking a license, and the person responsible may be punished as for violations of other city ordinances. (Code 1967, § 12½-74) Sec. 22-135. - Deadline penalties. Failure to file reports and pay the license fees herein levied before the same become delinquent shall subject such corporation or association to an additional ten percent of the amount required to be paid as a penalty for such negligence and delinquency. Further, all amounts not paid by due date shall bear interest at the legal rate as prescribed by the laws of the state. (Code 1967, § 12½-75) Sec. 22-136. - Repeal of conflicting provisions. All ordinances and parts of ordinances in conflict herewith are hereby repealed. National banks and banking associations, federal savings and loan associations, banks organized and chartered under the laws of the state, and any corporation doing banking business shall be excluded from the levy and assessment of business license fees and taxes under provisions of that certain ordinance of the city, adopted December 20, 1971, to levy and assess special taxes for the city. The provisions of such ordinance in so far as the same relate to corporations and associations doing banking business as classified in this section are hereby repealed. (Code 1967, § 12½-76) Secs. 22-137—22-160. - Reserved. ARTICLE VII. - FIREARMS DEALERS DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 22-161. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Dealer means any person regularly engaged in the business of selling firearms. Department means the city department of public safety. Firearms means any pistol, revolver or derringer, by whatever name known, which is designed to expel projectiles by the action of an explosive. Identification means any driver's license, birth certificate, U.S. passport, U.S. military identification card, baptismal or christening certificate, or employee's identification card, provided the same shows the age and home address of the employee. (Ord. No. O-90-06, § 16-71, 5-7-90) Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Sec. 22-162. - Recordkeeping. Each dealer within the city shall maintain complete and adequate records reflecting the disposition, at wholesale or retail, of all firearms physically or constructively disposed of in the course of this business. Entries of such records shall be posted at the time of each transaction. The records required by this section shall be in permanent form and shall be retained on the business premises of the dealer for a period of not less than ten years from the date the transaction occurs or until discontinuance of business by the dealer. Where there is a discontinuance of business by the dealer, all records of sales of firearms shall be delivered to the department within 90 days of the discontinuance. Where there is a transfer of the business of a dealer to new owner, the records will reflect those facts and will be delivered to the successor dealer. The records will show and include: (1) A full and adequate description of each firearm including: a. The manufacturer thereof; b. The manufacturer's serial number stamped thereon; c. The caliber of the firearm; and d. The model and type of firearm. (2) The disposition made of each firearm including the name, address and age of the person to whom sold and the date of disposition. (3) The evidence of identification furnished to the dealer by the purchaser. (4) A statement signed by purchaser setting forth: a. The purchaser's age; b. That the purchaser is not a fugitive from justice; c. That the purchaser is not under indictment or has not been convicted of a crime punishable by imprisonment for a term exceeding one year by or in any court; and d. That the purchase is made for the sole use of purchaser or members of the purchaser's immediate family. (Ord. No. O-90-06, § 16-72, 5-7-90) Sec. 22-163. - Fingerprint record. (a) In addition to the other records and information as called for in section 22-162, each dealer shall obtain from each person purchasing any firearm the fingerprint of the righthand index finger, unless that finger is missing in which event the print of the next finger in existence on the right hand of the person purchasing the firearm shall be obtained, with a notation as to the exact finger printed. If the purchaser has no right hand, the dealer shall require the fingerprint of the lefthand index finger, unless that finger is missing, in which event the print of the next finger in existence on the left hand of the person purchasing the firearm shall be obtained, with a notation as to the exact finger printed. Fingerprints and the information, as required in this section, shall be obtained from all persons each time that a person purchases any firearm, regardless of whether or not that person may have previously purchased a firearm from the dealer and been fingerprinted. (b) Failure to fingerprint the person purchasing a firearm shall constitute an offense under this article. (Ord. No. O-90-06, § 16-73, 5-7-90) Sec. 22-164. - Records subject to inspection by department of public safety. All records required to be kept under the provisions of section 22-162 and all firearms held for resale by any dealer shall be subject to inspection by officers and agents of the department during regular business hours or, if regular business hours are not maintained, upon demand during the daytime. (Ord. No. O-90-06, § 16-74, 5-7-90) Sec. 22-165. - Compliance with article by dealer and purchaser. Any failure to comply with the terms and provisions of this article by any dealer, or the furnishing of any false identification or statement by any purchaser under this article shall constitute an offense by the dealer or purchaser under this article. (Ord. No. O-90-06, § 16-75, 5-7-90) Sec. 22-166. - Sale and distribution of replica firearms. (a) Except as provided in this section, no person shall market for sale, distribute, or sell a replica or facsimile of a firearm which is a toy or imitation firearm which substantially duplicates an actual pistol or revolver. (b) As used in this section, the term "replica or facsimile of a firearm" shall include any device or object made of plastic, wood, or metal, or any other material, which can reasonably be perceived as an actual firearm. Such term does not include nonfiring replica of an antique firearm, nor shall it include starter pistols used in athletic events. (Ord. No. O-90-06, § 16-76, 5-7-90) Secs. 22-167—22-185. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - CERTIFICATE OF APPROVAL
Sec. 22-186. - Application of division. This division shall not be construed to apply to toy pistols, toy revolvers or toy weapons of any kind, or to antique weapons which are used only for display. This division shall further not apply to casual sales between bona fide gun collectors, nor shall this division apply to any marshal, deputy marshal, sheriff, prison or jail warden, deputy prison or jail warden, correctional officer, police officer or other authorized law officer. No person regularly engaged in the manufacture, repair or sale of firearms shall be required to make application to obtain firearms as provided by this division. (Ord. No. O-90-06, § 16-71(l), 5-7-90) Sec. 22-187. - Compliance with division and furnishing of purchaser's identity required prior to sale, transfer, delivery or disposal. It shall be unlawful for any dealer in firearms or for any employee, servant or agent of such dealer, to sell, transfer, deliver or dispose of, in any way, any firearms unless the person obtaining the firearm shall furnish identification to the dealer setting forth the person's name, present address and age. No dealer in firearms, nor any employee, servant or agent of such dealer, shall sell, transfer, deliver or dispose of, in any way, a pistol, revolver or short-barrelled firearm, the barrel of which is less than 15 inches in length, to any person within the city unless there shall first have been compliance with each provision of this division. For the purpose of this division, a dealer in firearms shall include any person engaged in the business of operating a pawnshop or other place where money is advanced on goods or other effects, or merchandise of any kind is taken in pawn. (Ord. No. O-90-06, § 16-71, 5-7-90) Sec. 22-188. - Penalty for violation of division. Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this article shall be subject to punishment as provided in section 1-12. (Ord. No. O-90-06, § 16-71(m), 5-7-90) Sec. 22-189. - Required. No dealer in firearms, or any employee, servant or agent of such dealer, shall sell, transfer, deliver or dispose of in any way a pistol, revolver or short-barrelled firearm less than 15 inches in length as provided herein, unless the prospective purchaser shall have first obtained a certificate of approval from the director of public safety of the city and submitted such to the dealer. (Ord. No. O-90-06, § 16-71(a), 5-7-90) Sec. 22-190. - Application; contents. The applicant shall file with the department of public safety an application furnished by the department stating the applicant's name, including any and all names by which the applicant may have previously been known; sex, race, age, height, color of hair, color of eyes; present address; any and all addresses for the applicant within the past five years; whether the applicant has been convicted of any crime of violence within the past five years; whether the applicant has been convicted of any felony related to firearms, sex, alcohol or drug offenses within the past five years; whether the applicant has been found guilty of the violation of any law governing the use of firearms within the past five years; whether the applicant is presently a fugitive from justice from any police jurisdiction within the United States; whether the applicant is presently suffering from any mental illness; whether the applicant has been treated for any mental illness within the past ten years, and if so, the location of the hospital or mental institution providing such treatment; and whether the applicant presently has a valid permit issued pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 16-11-129, and, if so, the date of issuance and the county of issuance of such permit. The application shall also provide the name and address of the dealer from whom the purchaser will purchase the firearm and the date such application is completed by the applicant. (Ord. No. O-90-06, § 16-71(b), 5-7-90) Sec. 22-191. - Applicant fingerprints; background history (criminal record); hospital or mental institution records. (a) The applicant shall provide a full set of fingerprints as may be required by the department of public safety; furthermore the applicant shall authorize said department to conduct a background history of any criminal record which the applicant may have related to his or her qualifications to purchase a firearm pursuant to this section. The applicant shall further authorize the department to obtain such hospital or mental institution records as may be required to determine the applicant's qualifications for purposes of this section. (b) After receipt of the application, the director of public safety or his designee shall conduct an investigation of the applicant, including a search of the applicant's fingerprint records, and hospital or mental institution records, if any. (Ord. No. O-90-06, § 16-71(c), (d), 5-7-90) Sec. 22-192. - Application processing fee. The applicant shall pay to the department of public safety a fee as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges for the processing of the application, and such fee shall be paid at the time the application is delivered to the department. (Ord. No. O-90-06, § 16-71(e), 5-7-90) Sec. 22-193. - Approval; disapproval generally. Within 15 days for a state resident or not less than one year and 60 days for a nonresident, from the delivery of the application provided in this division to the department of public safety, the director of public safety or his designee shall notify the dealer, indicated on the subject application in writing, of the approval or disapproval of the applicant; provided, however, that no dealer shall sell, transfer, deliver or dispose of, in any way, any firearms, as provided in this division, until and unless such dealer is notified of the approval by the director of public safety or his designee. Such approval shall remain in effect for a period of 90 days after the effective date thereof, and, if approved, such approval shall only permit the applicant to obtain a firearm from the dealer whose name shall appear upon the application. If disapproved, the dealer shall not sell, transfer, deliver or dispose of, in any way, any firearm to such applicant, and the applicant shall not make any further application until the expiration of six months after the effective date of such disapproval. (Ord. No. O-90-06, § 16-71(f), 5-7-90) Sec. 22-194. - Conditions for disapproval. The director of public safety or his designee shall disapprove the disposition if the director or his designee shall determine that any of the following conditions apply to the applicant: (1) Such applicant has been convicted of a crime of violence within the past five years. For the purposes of this subsection, a crime of violence shall mean murder, manslaughter, rape, mayhem, assault, aggravated assault, assault with intent to murder, assault with intent to rape, assault with intent to rob, simple assault, simple battery, aggravated battery, robbery, burglary, kidnapping, or the crime of attempting to commit any of such crimes. (2) Such applicant has been convicted of any felony related to firearms, sex, alcohol or drug offenses within the past five years. (3) Such applicant has been found guilty of the violation of any law governing the use of firearms within the past five years. (4) Such applicant is presently a fugitive from justice from any police jurisdiction within the United States. (5) Such applicant is presently suffering from any mental illness. (6) Such applicant fails or refuses to complete the application or fails or refuses to complete any part of the application process. (7) Such applicant is under 21 years of age at the time the application is submitted to the department. (Ord. No. O-90-06, § 16-71(g), 5-7-90) Sec. 22-195. - Approval; obtaining firearms from dealer not on application. (a) The issuance of a pistol permit to the applicant under the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 16-11-129, shall be prima facie evidence of good cause for the approval of the application by the director of public safety or his designee. (b) If the application is approved and the applicant elects to obtain a firearm from a dealer other than the dealer whose name appears upon the application, the applicant shall notify the department of the name and the address of such dealer, and the department shall promptly notify such dealer, in writing, of the applicant's eligibility to obtain a firearm. (Ord. No. O-90-06, § 16-71(h), (i), 5-7-90) Sec. 22-196. - Revocation of eligibility. If at any time during the period for which the applicant retains his eligibility to obtain a firearm, the director of public safety or his designee shall learn or have brought to his attention in any manner any reasonable ground to believe the applicant is not entitled to retain his eligibility to obtain a firearm, the director or his designee may revoke the applicant's eligibility and shall promptly notify the dealer whose name appears upon the application of such revocation. The director or his designee shall further confiscate from the applicant any firearm obtained in contravention of the provisions of this division. (Ord. No. O-90-06, § 16-71(j), 5-7-90) Sec. 22-197. - Notification of disapproval or revocation; right of appeal. If an applicant's eligibility is revoked, or if the applicant's application is disapproved, both as provided in this division, the director of public safety or his designee shall promptly notify the applicant of such disapproval or revocation and shall further notify the applicant that the applicant shall have the right to appeal the disapproval or revocation to the city commission. After a hearing, the action of the director of public safety or his designee shall be either affirmed or overruled. (Ord. No. O-90-06, § 16-71(k), 5-7-90) Sec. 22-198. - False information. It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly provide false information on an application to obtain firearms, as provided in this division. (Ord. No. O-90-06, § 16-71(l), 5-7-90) Secs. 22-199—22-225. - Reserved. ARTICLE VIII. - PAWNSHOPS[7]
Footnotes: --- (7) --- State Law reference— Pawnbrokers, O.C.G.A. § 44-12-130 et seq.
Sec. 22-226. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Employee means any person working for an owner or pawnbroker, or any owner or pawnbroker who, in the performance of duties or the management of the business affairs of a pawnshop, comes into substantial contact with members of the public, or is employed on a part-time or full-time basis, either with or without remuneration, by a pawnshop. Pawn or pledge means a bailment of personal property as security for any debt or engagement, redeemable upon certain terms and with the implied power of sale on default. Pawnbroker means any person, whether an owner or not, who works in a pawnshop on a regular basis and in a managerial capacity whereby the person has charge of the business or operations of the pawnshop. Pawnbroker includes any person whose business or occupation it is to take or receive, by way of pledge, pawn or exchange, any goods, wares or merchandise or any kind of personal property whatever, as security for the repayment of money lent thereon. Pawnshop means any business wherein a substantial part thereof is to take or receive, by way of pledge, pawn or exchange, any goods, wares, merchandise or any kind of personal property as security for the repayment of money lent thereon. (Ord. No. O-92-20, § 12½-102, 12-21-92) Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Sec. 22-227. - Penalty for violation of article; suspension or revocation of license. (a) Any person who violates any provision of this article shall, upon conviction, be punished as provided in section 1-12. (b) Any person failing to comply with any provision of this article, or such other laws, ordinances and regulations as may be passed by the city commissioners for the conduct of the business of a pawnbroker, or who is convicted in any court for a violation of any provision of this article or any other ordinance or regulation covering the conduct of the business for which a permit and license have been issued shall be subject to the denial, suspension or revocation of the business license. (Ord. No. O-92-20, § 12½-103, 12-21-92) Sec. 22-228. - Responsibility for enforcement. The public safety department shall have the responsibility for the enforcement of this article. (Ord. No. O-92-20, § 12½-104, 12-21-92) Sec. 22-229. - Annual permit and license. (a) All persons, before beginning the business of operating a pawnshop or becoming an employee of a pawnshop or similar place where money is advanced on goods or other effects or merchandise of any kind is taken in pawn, shall first file an application with the public safety department and obtain an annual permit to conduct or be employed in the business. No permit shall be issued until a fee in the amount established by the city commissioners and set forth in the schedule of fees and charges is paid to the city clerk. (b) All pawnshops shall have a valid business license. The requirements of this section are in addition to the requirements of article II of this chapter. (c) The application for the permit required shall state the street and number at which it is proposed to operate the business. The application shall contain the full name, address, phone number, date of birth and social security number of all persons, including pawnbrokers, owning any interest in the proposed business, plus any additional information, including fingerprints, deemed necessary by the public safety department. (d) No business license shall be issued to a person until the permit required by this section has been approved by the public safety department. (Ord. No. O-92-20, § 12½-105, 12-21-92) Sec. 22-230. - Employees. No person shall be employed by a pawnshop in any capacity until such person has been fingerprinted by the public safety department and has been issued an annual permit authorizing such person to be employed by a pawnshop. It shall be the duty of the pawnbroker to ensure that there is compliance with the provisions of this section. (Ord. No. O-92-20, § 12½-106, 12-21-92) Sec. 22-231. - Character of persons connected with business. No owner, stockholder, employee, pawnbroker or any other person connected with the business for which a license or permit is sought shall have been convicted of a crime involving moral turpitude or shall have been convicted of any crime involving theft or a crime against property. (Ord. No. O-92-20, § 12½-107, 12-21-92) Sec. 22-232. - Records. All pawnbrokers shall keep books wherein shall be entered an accurate description of all property pledged, traded or sold to them. This description shall include, to the extent possible, the name of the maker of the article, any identifying mark or number and a statement of the kind of material of which it is made. In these books there shall be entered also the full name and address of the person by whom it was deposited or sold, and the time when it was done. These entries shall be made as soon after the transaction as is possible, but in no event more than one hour thereafter. The pawnbroker shall photograph the person pawning the merchandise along with a pawnbroker's ticket showing a transaction number. The pawnbroker shall obtain the right index fingerprint, provided it has not been amputated; if so, the next adjoining finger shall be acceptable. (Ord. No. O-92-20, § 12½-108, 12-21-92) Sec. 22-233. - Daily reports; fingerprinting and photographing of persons pawning articles. (a) Every pawnbroker shall make a daily report in writing to the public safety department in such form as may be prescribed by the public safety department of all property pledged, traded or bought by such pawnbroker during the 24 hours ending at 9:00 p.m. on the date of the report. These reports shall be typewritten. In addition to any other information required by the public safety department, the reports shall show: (1) The name and address of the pawnbroker. (2) The time of transaction. (3) The serial numbers of pawn tickets. (4) The amount paid or advanced. (5) A full description of articles, including kind, style, material, color, design; kind and number of stones in jewelry; and all identifying names, marks and numbers. (6) A description of the person selling or pawning, including name, address, race, weight and height. (b) Insufficient reports shall be rejected, and any pawnbroker making them shall be deemed guilty of an offense. (c) In addition to the other records and information, each pawnbroker shall obtain from each person pawning any articles with such pawnbroker the fingerprint of the righthand index finger, unless this finger is missing, in which event the print of the next finger in existence on the right hand of the person pawning the articles shall be obtained with a notation as to the exact finger printed. All prints shall be made on forms approved by the public safety department, and the pawnbroker shall obtain all other information called for on the approved form. Fingerprints and the information, as required in this section, shall be obtained from all persons each time these persons pawn any article with a pawnbroker, regardless of whether the person may have previously pawned an article with the pawnbroker and been fingerprinted. (d) In addition to other records and information, each pawnbroker shall photograph each customer with the photograph showing the pawnbroker's ticket and transaction number. This photograph shall be reduced to a negative form and maintained by the pawnbroker as a permanent record. (Ord. No. O-92-20, § 12½-109, 12-21-92) Sec. 22-234. - Hours of operation. Pawnbrokers may not keep open their places of business except between 7:00 a.m. and 9:00 p.m., Monday through Saturday. (Ord. No. O-92-20, § 12½-110, 12-21-92) Sec. 22-235. - Waiting period prior to disposal of articles. Any pawnbroker or person operating under a pawnbroker's license who takes goods on pawn or buys goods, taking full title thereto, the word "goods" being used in the broadest sense and including all kinds of personal property, shall hold these goods so taken in pawn or purchase for at least 30 days before disposing of them by sale, transfer, shipment or otherwise. (Ord. No. O-92-20, § 12½-111, 12-21-92) Sec. 22-236. - Dealing with minors. It shall be unlawful for any pawnbroker, the pawnbroker's agents or employees to receive goods in pawn from minors. (Ord. No. O-92-20, § 12½-112, 12-21-92)

div.head: Chapter 26 - CEMETERIES[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Editor's note— Ord. No. O-13-02, adopted February 4, 2013, repealed the former ch. 26, §§ 26-1—26-12, and enacted a new ch. 26 as set out herein.
