The former ch. 26 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Code 1967, §§ 7-1, 7-2, 7-4, 7-6—7-14. Cross reference— Parks and recreation, ch. 74. State Law reference— Criminal trespass and damage to property, O.C.G.A. § 16-7-20 et seq.; abandoned cemeteries and burial grounds, O.C.G.A. § 36-72-1 et seq.; Georgia Cemetery Act of 1983, O.C.G.A. § 44-3-130 et seq.
Sec. 26-1. - Penalty for violation of chapter. Any person guilty of a violation of this chapter shall be punished as provided in section 1-12. (Ord. No. O-13-02, 2-4-13) Sec. 26-2. - Control and supervision of cemetery. (a) The city manager is hereby vested with the power and authority to control and supervise any improvements, changes in contour of lots or any other change of any kind or character to any of the lots located in the Decatur Cemetery. For purposes of this chapter, "city manager" means the person designated by the city commission as the city manager or his or her designee. (b) No such changes or improvements shall be made to any of such lots without first securing the written approval of the city manager and then only under direct supervision and direction of the city manager. (c) Except as permitted by section 26-5, all improvements or alterations to individual lots in the cemetery shall be undertaken in compliance with the direction of and subject to the consent, satisfaction and approval of the city manager; and should such improvements or alterations be made without the city manager written consent, the city shall have the right to remove, alter or change such improvements or alterations and to assess the costs of such work against the lot or the owner of the lot. (d) All work on lots within the cemetery, including all grading, landscape work, improvements, and care of any kind, all planting, trimming, cutting and removing of trees and shrubs of any kind, all opening and closing of graves, and all interments, disinterments and removals, shall be made in compliance with the authority of the city manager, including all rules that may from time to time be adopted for the cemetery. (e) Employees of the City of Decatur shall have the authority to remove all floral designs, flowers, weeds, trees, shrubs, and plants of any kind from the cemetery, both in public areas and on privately owned lots, when, in the judgment of the city manager such objects become dangerous, detrimental, diseased or in a state of disrepair. (f) All marker restoration and repair of individual lots in the 1828 historic section of the cemetery shall be under the direction of and subject to the written approval of the city manager or his or her designee. (Ord. No. O-13-02, 2-4-13) Sec. 26-3. - Prices of lots, charges and fees. Prices of lots, charges and fees for services offered in Decatur Cemetery shall be established by the city commission and set forth in the schedule of fees and charges. (Ord. No. O-13-02, 2-4-13) Sec. 26-4. - Purchase of lots by residents; resale to nonresidents. The prices of lots in Decatur Cemetery purchased by residents shall apply to bona fide and legal residents of the city. Any such resident, before purchasing any lots in the cemetery, shall provide the city manager with sufficient proof of legal residency within the city, and such purchaser shall agree that they will not sell or dispose of any such lot or part thereof to a nonresident of the city without first obtaining written consent from the city manager. If such consent is obtained and such resale is made, then such new purchaser or transferee shall pay to the city an amount equal to the difference between the current resident graves or lot price and the current nonresident grave or lot price for each lot or grave that is resold. In the event of a violation of this section, the lot shall revert to the city, and the owner thereof shall be reimbursed in the amount originally paid therefor. (Ord. No. O-13-02, 2-4-13) Sec. 26-5. - Placement of gravestone or markers. (a) When a gravestone or marker is placed above a grave by any firm or person licensed to perform such work in the Decatur Cemetery, the same shall be set in a concrete foundation of a size and type approved by the city manager, such work to be performed by the city and paid for by the person or firm requesting such foundation work, based on the current fee schedule of the cemetery. (b) It shall be unlawful for any lot owner, or any agent or employee of such lot owner, to place any marker in a manner otherwise than as provided by this section, including all rules that may from time to time be adopted for the cemetery. (Ord. No. O-13-02, 2-4-13) Sec. 26-6. - Mausoleums, tombs, or other edifices; removal. It shall be unlawful for any person in Decatur Cemetery, to erect, construct or build on any lot in the cemetery any mausoleum, tomb or other edifice of like kind or character or any edifice other than what is commonly termed a monument or marker and in keeping with monuments and markers now erected in the cemetery without first obtaining the written permission of the city manager. Upon the violation of this section, the city reserves the right to remove any such edifice from any such lot and to assess the costs of such removal against the lot, the owner of the lot, or the person erecting the edifice. (Ord. No. O-13-02, 2-4-13) Sec. 26-7. - Trees. It shall be unlawful for any person to plant any tree in Decatur Cemetery without first obtaining the written permission of the city manager. (Ord. No. O-13-02, 2-4-13) Sec. 26-8. - Shrubbery over three feet in height. It shall be unlawful for any person to plant upon any lot in Decatur Cemetery any shrubbery that exceeds three feet in height at the time of such planting, without first obtaining written permission of the city manager. (Ord. No. O-13-02, 2-4-13) Sec. 26-9. - Removal of trees and shrubbery. (a) The city reserves the right to remove any trees or shrubbery prohibited by sections 26-7 and 26-8 from any lot in Decatur Cemetery and to assess the costs of such removal against the owner of the lot or against the person planting such trees or shrubbery. (b) If any tree or shrub, situated in any lot, shall, by means of its roots or branches, become detrimental in any way to the adjoining lot, drive or walk, the city shall have the authority to enter upon the lot and remove the tree or shrub, or any part thereof. However, no tree growing in any lot shall be pruned or removed without the written consent of the city manager. (Ord. No. O-13-02, 2-4-13) Sec. 26-10. - Animals. (a) All animals in the Decatur Cemetery must be kept under restraint as defined in sections 14-31 and 14-34. (b) It shall be unlawful for any person who possesses, harbors or is in charge of any domestic restrained animal not to immediately remove excrement deposited by the animal while in the Decatur Cemetery. Animal waste must be removed and deposited in suitable sanitary containers. (Ord. No. O-13-02, 2-4-13) Sec. 26-11. - Erection of walls, coping and curbing. It shall be unlawful for any person to build or erect any wall, coping or curbing in, around or on any lot in Decatur Cemetery lying outside of the 1828 historic section of the cemetery, without first obtaining written permission of the city manager. (Ord. No. O-13-02, 2-4-13) Sec. 26-12. - Obstruction of walks or drives. It shall be unlawful for any person to block or obstruct any of the walks or drives in Decatur Cemetery without the permission of the city manager. (Ord. No. O-13-02, 2-4-13) Sec. 26-13. - Hours for cemetery. The Decatur Cemetery shall open at 7:00 a.m. and shall close at one-half hour after sunset; provided, however, that the closing time may be extended if at the regularly scheduled closing time there is an ongoing activity supervised by the city or having a permit issued by the city, in which event the closing time shall be ten minutes after the end of such supervised activity or permitted event. (Ord. No. O-13-02, 2-4-13)

div.head: Chapter 30 - CIVIL EMERGENCIES[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Emergency services, ch. 38; law enforcement, ch. 62; offenses and miscellaneous provisions, ch. 70. State Law reference— Authority to adopt temporary or experimental traffic regulations to cover emergencies or special conditions, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-371(a)(19); Georgia Mutual Aid Act, O.C.G.A. § 36-69-1 et seq.; Georgia Emergency Management Act of 1981, O.C.G.A. § 38-3-1 et seq.; interstate Civil Defense and Disaster Compact, O.C.G.A. § 38-3-70 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 30-1—30-30. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT
Sec. 30-31. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Emergency management means the preparation for and the carrying out of all emergency and disaster functions, other than those functions for which military forces or state and federal agencies are primarily responsible, to prevent, minimize, and repair injury and damage resulting from emergencies or disasters, or the imminent threat thereof, of manmade or natural origin. These functions may include, without limitation, firefighting services, police services, medical and health services, rescue, engineering, warning services, communications, protection against the effects of radiological, chemical and other special weapons, evacuation of persons from stricken areas, emergency welfare services, emergency transportation, plant protection, shelter, temporary restoration of public utility services, and other functions related to civilian population, together with all other activities necessary or incidental to total emergency and disaster preparedness for carrying out such functions. (Ord. No. O-94-10, § 17½-40, 7-5-94) Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Sec. 30-32. - Penalty for violation of article. Any person violating any provision of this article, or any rule, order, or regulation made pursuant to this article, shall, upon conviction thereof, be punishable as provided in section 1-12. (Ord. No. O-94-10, § 17½-45, 7-5-94) Sec. 30-33. - County emergency management director; duties. It is the desire and intent of the governing officials of the city that the city be a part of the county emergency management unit. The chief executive officer of the county shall nominate for appointment, by the governor, a director of emergency management for the entire county. When appointed, the emergency management director is charged with the following duties: (1) Represent the governing officials of the city on matters pertaining to emergency management. (2) Assist city officials in organizing city departments for emergency operations. (3) Develop, in conjunction with city and county departments, the county emergency and disaster operations plan emergency functions set forth in section 30-31. The plan will be in consonance with the state natural disaster operations plan and nuclear emergency operations plan and shall be submitted to the governing officials of the county and the cities therein for approval and thence to the state emergency management agency for approval. (4) Maintain the emergency management office and carry out the day-to-day administration of the county emergency management program, including the submission of required reports, to the state emergency management agency. (5) Submit reports as necessary as required by governing officials in keeping with good management practices. (6) Obtain, with the authority of governing officials, a facility to be used as the county emergency operating center. (7) Coordinate the activities of the county emergency operating center staff during periods of an emergency, and under supervision of county governing officials. (Ord. No. O-94-10, § 17½-41, 7-5-94) Sec. 30-34. - County emergency management office; assignment of emergency functions. The county emergency management office shall be established around existing city and county departments, and the emergency functions described in section 30-31 are assigned as follows:
(Ord. No. O-94-10, § 17½-42, 7-5-94) Sec. 30-35. - Powers during an emergency or disaster. In the event of a manmade or natural disaster, actual enemy attack upon the United States, or any other emergency which may affect the lives and property of citizens of the city, the mayor of the city, separately, or jointly with the CEO, county commission or in their absences, their legally appointed successors, may determine that an emergency or disaster exists and thereafter shall have and may exercise for such period as such emergency or disaster exists or continues, the following powers: (1) Enforce all rules, laws, and regulations relating to emergency management and to assume direct operational control over all emergency management resources; (2) Seize or take for temporary use, any private property for the protection of the public; (3) Sell, lend, give or distribute all or any such property or supplies among the inhabitants of the county and to maintain a strict accounting of property or supplies distributed and for funds received for such property or supplies; and (4) Perform and exercise such other functions and duties, and take such emergency actions as may be necessary to promote and secure the safety, protection and well-being of the inhabitants of the county. (Ord. No. O-94-10, § 17½-43, 7-5-94) Sec. 30-36. - Volunteers. All persons, other than officers and employees of the city, performing emergency functions pursuant to this article, shall serve with or without compensation. While engaged in such emergency functions, duly assigned volunteers shall have the same immunities as city officers and employees. (Ord. No. O-94-10, § 17½-44, 7-5-94)

div.head: Chapter 34 - ELECTIONS[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Administration, ch. 2. State Law reference— Georgia Municipal Election Code, O.C.G.A. § 21-3-1 et seq.
Sec. 34-1. - City to maintain elector's registration list. Pursuant to the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 21-3-125(d) the city elects to maintain its own voter registration list. (Code 1967, § 7½-1)

div.head: Chapter 38 - EMERGENCY SERVICES[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Civil emergencies, ch. 30; law enforcement, ch. 62; offenses and miscellaneous provisions, ch. 70; traffic and vehicles, ch. 98.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 38-1—38-30. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - ALARM SYSTEMS[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- State Law reference— Operation of electronic alarm systems by county or municipality, O.C.G.A. § 36-60-12; license required to engage in low voltage alarm system contracting, O.C.G.A. § 43-14-8.1.
Sec. 38-31. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Automatic dialing device means any device connected to a security alarm system which automatically sends a prerecorded message or coded signal indicating the activation of the security alarm system to a predetermined location. Calendar year means the period of time from January 1 through December 31. False alarm means the activation of a security alarm system by other than a forced entry or attempted forced entry to the premises and at a time when no burglary or robbery is being committed or attempted on the premises. Response means the dispatch of a police officer to the premises where a security alarm system has been activated. Security alarm system means an assembly of equipment and/or devices designated and arranged to detect and signal an unauthorized intrusion into premises or to signal an attempted burglary or robbery on protected premises, and, with respect to such signal, department of public safety personnel are expected to respond. (Ord. No. O-93-09, § 16-70, 12-20-93) Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Sec. 38-32. - Penalty for violation of article. (a) Any person or business violating or failing to comply with any of the provisions of this article shall be summoned to the municipal court for each violation and noncompliance and, upon conviction, shall be punished as provided in section 1-12. (b) The city and the city schools shall be exempt from compliance with this article for security alarm systems installed in city-owned facilities within the boundaries of the city. (Ord. No. O-93-09, § 16-71, 12-20-93) Sec. 38-33. - Prohibited acts. (a) It is unlawful for anyone to activate any security alarm system for the purpose of summoning police except in the event of an actual or attempted burglary or robbery or other unauthorized intrusion into premises. (b) It is unlawful for anyone to notify the department of public safety of an activated security alarm system while having knowledge that such activation was apparently caused by an electrical or other malfunction of the security alarm system or by maintenance or service to the security alarm system and/or to fail at the same time to notify the police of such apparent malfunction or repair. (c) It is unlawful to directly notify the department of public safety of any alarm activation by means of any automatic dialing device or any telephonic recording, message, signal, or warning. (Ord. No. O-93-09, § 16-72, 12-20-93) Sec. 38-34. - False alarm fines. For a response to any false alarm, the municipal court shall fine and collect such fines as follows from the person or business having and/or maintaining a security alarm system on the premises owned or occupied by such person: (1) For a first response to premises at which no other false alarm has occurred within a calendar year, there shall be no penalty. (2) For a second response to premises after a first response within a calendar year period, a written warning and a copy of this article shall be given, but the person having or maintaining such security alarm shall, within three working days after notice to do so, make a written report to the police chief, and if applicable, on prescribed forms setting forth the cause of such false alarm, the corrective action taken, whether such alarm has been inspected by an authorized service person, and such other information as may be required to determine the cause of such false alarm and necessary corrective action. Provision of this information is the sole responsibility of the offender. (3) For a third response to premises after a second response within a calendar year period, a fine as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges shall be charged, but a written report may be required as for a second response and the police chief shall be authorized to inspect or cause to be inspected the security alarm system at the owner's expense by a certified service person and to prescribe necessary corrective action. (4) For a fourth and a fifth response to premises after a third and/or fourth response within a calendar year, a fine as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges shall be charged, but a written report may be required as for a third and/or fourth response, and the police chief shall be authorized to inspect or cause to be inspected the security alarm system at such premises, prescribe necessary corrective action, and shall give notice to the person or business having or maintaining such security alarm system of the conditions and requirements of this article, including the fee requirements for six or more false alarm responses by the police division within each calendar year. (5) After a sixth response to premises within a calendar year, and for all succeeding responses within that calendar year, a fine as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges shall be charged, and if such false alarms are as a result of failure to take necessary corrective action prescribed by the police chief, disconnection of such security alarm system may be ordered. It shall be unlawful to reconnect such security alarm system until such corrective action is taken. No disconnection shall be ordered as to any premises required by law to have a security alarm system in operation. (Ord. No. O-93-09, § 16-73, 12-20-93) Sec. 38-35. - User fees. Any person or business which maintains a security alarm system or fire alarm system which has a direct connection to an alarm display panel located in the communications center of the department of public safety shall be charged a fee per month, as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges, for such connection. (Ord. No. O-93-09, § 16-74, 12-20-93) Sec. 38-36. - Requirements for owners of businesses, residences or structures. The owner of each business, residence, or structure equipped with a security alarm system must provide the police department or their alarm company with a minimum of three emergency phone numbers of persons who can be contacted in the case of an emergency or malfunction of the system. Listed persons must be able to enter the business, residence, or structure and secure the system within 30 minutes of its reported failure. These names and numbers shall also be posted in a conspicuous location on the premises where an independent alarm is located. (Ord. No. O-93-09, § 16-75, 12-20-93)

div.head: Chapter 42 - ENVIRONMENT[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Editor's note— Ord. No. O-14-Z-26, § 2, adopted Nov. 17, 2014, repealed arts. IV—XII, §§ 42-80—42-500, which pertained to soil erosion and sedimentation control, post-development stormwater management for new development and redevelopment, illicit discharge and illegal connection, stormwater management, stormwater management rates, floodplain management/flood damage prevention, Decatur greenspace commission, stream buffer protection, and miscellaneous—outdoor landscape watering, respectively; and derived from the Ord. No. O-99-20, 12-20-99; Ord. No. O-00-04, 3-20-00; Ord. No. O-02-02, 4-15-02; Ord. No. O-04-06, 3-15-04; Ord. No. O-04-07, 3-15-04; Ord. No. O-04-09, 3-15-04; Ord. No. O-05-02, 2-7-05; Ord. No. O-07-03, 1-16-07; Ord. No. O-07-15, 12-17-07; Ord. No. O-09-01, 2-2-09; Ord. No. O-10-03, 4-5-10; Ord. No. O-10-09, 12-6-10. Ord. No. O-14-Z-26, §§ 1, and 2, further amended and re-codified soil erosion and sedimentation control, post-development stormwater management for new development and redevelopment, illicit discharge and illegal connection, stormwater management, stormwater management rates, floodplain management/flood damage prevention, and stream buffer protection to read as set out in part IV of this Code, Unified Development Ordinance, art. 9; outdoor landscape watering to read as set out in § 7.2.3. of the UDO; and Decatur greenspace commission to read as set out in § 11.1.6. of the UDO. Cross reference— Health and sanitation, ch. 54; parks and recreation, ch. 74; solid waste, ch. 82; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 86.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 42-1. - Zoning board of appeals. The zoning board of appeals, as established in Appendix A, Zoning, of the Decatur Code of Ordinances, is designated to hear appeals and variance requests as specified in Chapter 42, Environment, of the Code of the City of Decatur, Georgia. (Ord. No. O-04-04, 3-15-04) Cross reference— Zoning Board of Appeals, App. A, Art. XII, et seq. Secs. 42-2—42-30. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - NUISANCES[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- State Law reference— Nuisances, O.C.G.A. § 41-1-1 et seq.
Sec. 42-31. - Provisions saved from repeal. Section 16-20 of the 1967 Code on the subject of nuisances is not repealed and shall continue in full force and effect pending a revision of the subject matter by the city. Secs. 42-32—42-55. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - NOISE[3]
Footnotes: --- (3) --- State Law reference— Limits on sound volume produced by radio, tape player or other mechanical sound-making device or instrument from within motor vehicle, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-14; sale of muffler which causes excessive noise prohibited, O.C.G.A. § 40-8-71(c).
Sec. 42-56. - Penalty for violation of article. Any person guilty of a violation of this article shall be punished as provided in section 1-12. (Code 1967, § 15-5) Sec. 42-57. - Creation of unreasonably loud and disturbing noises. Subject to the provisions of this article, the creating of any unreasonably loud, disturbing and unnecessary noise within the city is prohibited. (Code 1967, § 15-1) Sec. 42-58. - Noise detrimental to life or health, or disturbing the public peace or welfare. Noise of such character, intensity or duration as to be detrimental to the life or health of any individual or in disturbance of the public peace and welfare is prohibited. (Code 1967, § 15-2) Sec. 42-59. - Enumeration of certain loud, disturbing and unnecessary noises. The following acts, among others, are declared to be loud, disturbing and unnecessary noises and noises in violation of this article, but this enumeration shall not be deemed to be exclusive, namely: (1) Blowing horns or signaling devices. The sounding or blowing of any horn or signal device on any automobile, truck, bus, motorcycle or other vehicle while not in motion, except as a danger signal if another vehicle is approaching apparently out of control, or if in motion only as a danger signal after or as brakes are being applied and deceleration of the vehicle is intended; the creation by means of any such signal device of any unreasonably loud or harsh sound; and the sounding of such device for any unnecessary and unreasonable period of time. (2) Radios, televisions, musical instruments and similar devices. The following uses of radios, televisions, musical instruments and similar devices are prohibited: a. The operating or playing of any radio, musical instrument or similar device which produces or reproduces sound on the public rights-of-way in such manner as to be audible to any person other than the operator of the device. b. The operating or playing of any radio, television, phonograph, musical instrument or similar device which produces or reproduces sound in a motor vehicle or public park in a manner as to be audible at a distance of 50 feet. c. Loudspeakers and sound amplifiers. The using or operating of any loudspeaker, loudspeaker system, sound amplifier or other similar device between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. on weekdays, and 10:00 p.m. and 10:00 a.m. on weekends and holidays, within or adjacent to residential or noise sensitive areas such that the sound therefrom is audible across the real property line of the source; provided, however, that this shall not apply to any public performance, gathering or parade for which a permit has been obtained from the city. A "noise sensitive area" is an area where a school, hospital, nursing home, church, court, public library or cemetery is located. (3) Yelling, shouting, hooting, whistling or singing on streets. Yelling, shouting, hooting, whistling or singing on the public streets, particularly between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m., or at any time or place so as to annoy or disturb the quiet, comfort or repose of persons in any hospital, dwelling, hotel or other type of residence, or of persons in the vicinity. (4) Animals. The owning, possessing or harboring of any animal which frequently, or for continued duration, howls, barks, meows, squawks or makes other sound which creates excessive and unnecessary noise across a residential or commercial real property line or within a noise sensitive area. For the purposes of this subsection the term "barking dog" shall mean a dog that barks, bays, cries, howls or makes any other noise continuously and/or incessantly for a period of ten minutes, or barks intermittently for one-half hour or more to the disturbance of any person at any time of day or night, regardless of whether the dog is physically situated in or upon private property; provided, however, that a dog shall not be deemed a barking dog if, at the time the dog is barking or making any other noise, a person is trespassing or threatening to trespass upon property in or upon which the dog is situated. (5) Use of vehicles. The use of any automobile, truck, bus, motorcycle or other vehicle so out of repair or loaded in such manner as to create loud and unnecessary grating, grinding, rattling or other noise. (6) Blowing whistles. The blowing of any steam whistle attached to any stationary boiler, except to give notice of the time to begin or stop work, as a warning of fire or danger, or upon request of proper city authorities. (7) Exhaust discharge. To discharge into the open air the exhaust of any steam engine, stationary internal combustion engine, motor vehicle or motor boat engine, except through a muffler or other device which will effectively prevent loud or explosive noises therefrom. (8) Building operations, excavation of streets; permit from city manager. The erection (including excavation and site development), demolition, alteration or repair of any building in or within 300 feet of any residential zoning district in the city, and the excavation of streets and highways in or within 300 feet of any residential zoning district in the city, other than between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m., Monday through Friday and between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m. on Saturday, except in case of urgent necessity in the interest of public health and safety, and then only with a permit of the city manager, which permit may be granted for a period not to exceed 30 days while the emergency continues. Exception: This subsection shall not apply to operations which are carried on in such a manner or in such a location as not to create sound exceeding 60 dB(A), when measured at or beyond the property boundary of the property from which the sound emanates. (9) Noises near schools, hospitals, churches, court or institution of learning. The creation of any excessive noise on any street adjacent to any school, institution of learning, church or court while the same is in session, or adjacent to any hospital, which unreasonably interferes with the workings or sessions thereof, provided that signs must be displayed in such streets indicating that the same is a school, institution of learning, church, court or hospital. (10) Loading and unloading operations. The creation of loud and excessive noise in connection with loading or unloading any vehicle or the opening and destruction of bales, boxes, crates or containers. (11) Noise to attract attention. The use of any drum, loudspeaker or other instrument or device for the purpose of attracting attention by the creation of noise to any performance, show or sale or display of merchandise. (12) Loudspeakers or amplifiers on vehicles. The use of mechanical loudspeakers or amplifiers on automobiles, trucks, buses or other moving or standing vehicles for advertising or other purposes. (13) Emergency signaling devices. The following uses of emergency signaling devices are prohibited: a. Except in case of an emergency, the intentional sounding of any audible alarm between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. b. The testing of any alarm for a period in excess of 60 seconds at any time. c. Permitting an audible alarm which has been activated by a malfunction to continue for more than 30 minutes. (14) Maximum permissible sound levels; Table I. The following subsections and table detail the maximum permissible sound levels: a. No person shall operate or cause to be operated any source of sound from any location in such a manner as to create a sound level which exceeds the limits set forth in Table I for the receiving land use category more than ten percent of any measurement period, which period shall not be less than ten minutes, when measured at or beyond the property boundary of the property from which the sound emanates; provided, however, that in the case of the multifamily dwelling land use category, the sound level shall be measured within an adjacent intrabuilding dwelling. b. For any source of sound, the sound level shall not exceed the maximum permissible sound level limit set forth in Table I by 15 dB(A) for all land use categories. c. Sound level measurement shall be made with a sound level meter using the A-weighting scale in accordance with the standards promulgated by the American National Standards Institute (ANSI). TABLE I MAXIMUM PERMISSIBLE SOUND LEVELS BY RECEIVING LAND USE CATEGORY
Notes to Table I. 1. The term "land use category" shall mean the use for which the property is zoned in the zoning ordinance of the city. 2. The term "noise sensitive area" shall mean an area where a school, hospital, nursing home, church, court, public library or cemetery is located. (15) Exemptions. The following are exempt from the sound level limits of Table I: a. Noises resulting from any authorized emergency vehicles when responding to an emergency. b. Noises made by persons having obtained a parade or concert permit from the city. (Code 1967, § 15-3; Ord. No. O-90-10, 9-17-90; Ord. No. O-98-16, § 1, 8-3-98; Ord. No. O-00-07, § 1, 7-5-00; Ord. No. O-01-17, 9-4-01) Sec. 42-60. - Exemptions. None of the terms or prohibitions of this article shall apply to or be enforced against: (1) Any vehicle of the city while engaged in necessary public business. (2) Excavations or repairs of bridges, streets or highways by or on behalf of the city or the state, at night, when the public welfare and convenience renders it impossible to perform such work during the day. (Code 1967, § 15-4) Secs. 42-61—42-79. - Reserved.

div.head: Chapter 54 - HEALTH AND SANITATION[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Alcoholic beverages, ch. 6; amusements and entertainments, ch. 10; animals, ch. 14; businesses, ch. 22; environment, ch. 42; offenses and miscellaneous provisions, ch. 70; solid waste, ch. 82. State Law reference— Power of county board of health to adopt rules and regulations of local application, O.C.G.A. § 31-3-6; power of county board of health to adopt and enforce rules and regulations, O.C.G.A. § 31-3-4(a)(4).
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 54-1. - Violation of county health department rules and regulations for food service establishments; penalty for violation. Violations of the rules and regulations for food service establishments adopted October 11, 1977, by the county health department, occurring within the city, are declared to be unlawful and the municipal court shall have jurisdiction over persons charged with any such violation. The penalty for violation of any such rule or regulation shall be as provided by section 1-12. (Code 1967, § 16-41) State Law reference— Promulgation of rules, regulations and standards by state department of human resources and county boards of health, O.C.G.A. § 26-2-373. Secs. 54-2—54-30. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - CLEAN AIR ORDINANCE[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- Editor's note— Ord. No. O-04-13, adopted July 1, 2004, repealed the former art. II, §§ 54-31—54-37, and enacted a new art. II as set out herein. The former art. II pertained to smoking policy and derived from Ord. No. O-93-05, §§ 16-63—16-69, adopted July 6, 1993.
Sec. 54-31. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Child care facility means any institution, society, agency, or facility, whether incorporated or not, which either primarily or incidentally provides full-time care for children under 17 years of age outside their own homes, subject to such exceptions as may be provided in rules and regulations of the State Board of Human Resources, as defined by O.C.G.A. § 49-5-3, as amended. Dining area means an enclosed interior or exterior area containing a counter or tables upon which food is served. Employer means any person who employs the services of another person. Employee means any person who is employed by any employer in consideration for direct or indirect monetary wages of profit. Enclosed means closed in by a roof and at least three sides with appropriate openings for ingress and egress. It includes areas commonly described as public lobbies or lobbies when those are in an area that is enclosed as defined herein. Establishment means any business, store, office or other place where goods or services are sold or provided as part of a commercial venture. The term establishment includes but is not limited to the following: (1) automobile dealerships, furniture or other showrooms for the display of merchandise offered for sale; (2) grocery, pharmacy, specialty, department and other stores which sell goods or merchandise; (3) service stations, stores or shops for the repair or maintenance of appliances, shoes, motor vehicles or other items or products; (4) barbershops, beauty shops, cleaners, laundromats and other establishments offering services to the general public; (5) video arcade, pool hall and other amusement centers; (6) offices providing professional services such as legal, medical, dental, engineering and architectural services; (7) banks, savings and loan offices, and other financial establishments; (8) hotels and motels and other places that provide accommodations to the public; and, (9) restaurants and cafeterias. Health care facility means any licensed general or specialized hospital, institutional infirmary, public health center or diagnostic and treatment center, as defined by O.C.G.A. § 31-7-1(2), as amended. Intermediate care (nursing) home means any long-term custodial care facility that provides for the physical and mental welfare of the aged. Personal care home means a residential facility having at least 25 beds and providing, for compensation, protective care and oversight of ambulatory, nonrelated persons, including the elderly, who need a monitored environment but who do not have injuries or disabilities which require chronic or convalescent care, including medial, nursing, or intermediate care, personal care homes include those facilities which monitor daily residents' functioning and location, have the capability for crises intervention, and provide supervision in areas of nutrition, medication, and provision of transient medical care. Such term does not include residential facilities which are devoted to independent living units with kitchen facilities in which residents have the option of preparing and serving some or all of their own meals, or boarding facilities which do not provide personal care. Place of employment means any enclosed area under the control of a public or private employer which employees frequent during the course of employment including, but not limited to, work areas, restrooms, hallways, employee lounges, cafeterias and snack bars, conference and meeting rooms, lobbies and reception areas. (1) A private residence is not a place of employment unless it is used as a childcare facility, an adult day care facility, or a health care facility. (2) The dining area of a restaurant shall be treated as a place of employment under this article. Private enclosed offices means any enclosed area within a place of employment. Private enclosed offices must have walls that extend from floor to ceiling and a closable door. Public park means any public park, playground, greenspace, plaza or outdoor recreation area maintained and operated by the city, including but not limited to, all city parks, the MARTA Plaza, the Decatur Cemetery and the Old Courthouse lawn. Public place means any enclosed area to which the public is invited or in which the public is permitted including, but not limited to, restaurants; stores; waiting rooms; lobbies; reception areas, hallways, public transit; restrooms; enclosed shopping malls; elevators, service lines, service stations, offices providing professional services, banks and other financial institutions, educational, recreational and health care facilities; child care facilities; auditoriums; theaters; arenas; meeting rooms, repair shops, automobile dealerships, conventional halls, bowling facilities, polling places and bingo games. A private residence is not a public place unless it is used as a childcare facility, and adult day care facility or a health care facility. Restaurant means any establishment or enclosed area which is primarily devoted to the serving of food by which more than 50 percent of its total annual gross sales are derived from food sales to the public or guests and which contains a dining area; or, an establishment by which at least 40 percent of its total annual gross sales are from the sale of prepared meals or food and provides chairs, tables and counters to seat and serve 50 or more persons. The term restaurant shall include any dining area located within a health care, educational, or childcare facility. Food courts within enclosed shopping malls shall be treated as restaurants under this article. Retail tobacco store means a retail store utilized primarily for the sale of tobacco products and accessories and in which the sale of other products is merely incidental. Service line means any indoor line at which one or more persons are waiting for or receiving service of any kind, whether or not such service involved the exchange of money. Smoking means inhaling, exhaling, burning or carrying any lighted cigar, cigarette, e-cigarette, oral smoking device, or pipe containing any weed, plant, nicotine based liquid or other combustible substance in any manner or in any form. (Ord. No. O-04-13, 7-1-04; Ord. No. O-16-09, § 1, 5-16-16) Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Sec. 54-32. - Public places, places of employment, and public parks; generally. (a) Except as otherwise provided in this article, smoking is prohibited in all public places within the city, all places of employment within the city, and all public parks. All ashtrays and similar smoking paraphernalia shall be removed from any place where smoking is prohibited. (b) Except as otherwise provided in this article, smoking is prohibited: (1) Within 20 feet of any outside entrance, operable window or ventilation system of any public place within the city and of any place of employment within the city; (2) Within 20 feet of any exterior seating or service area of any restaurant within the city. (Ord. No. O-04-13, 7-1-04; Ord. No. O-16-09, § 2, 5-16-16) Sec. 54-33. - Exceptions. (a) The regulation of smoking pursuant to this article shall not apply in the following areas: (1) Designated smoking rooms in hotels and motels rented to guests, provided that such designated smoking rooms shall not comprise more than 25 percent of the total number of rooms available for rent. (2) Retail tobacco stores. (3) Private clubs when associated with and incidental to any apartment or office development. (4) Private residences, including those, which may serve as an office workplace, except if, used as a childcare, an adult day care or a health care facility. (5) Any property owned or leased by the State of Georgia or the federal government. (b) Notwithstanding any other provision of this article, any owner, operator, manager or other person who controls any establishment described in this article may declare that the entire establishment is a non-smoking establishment. (Ord. No. O-04-13, 7-1-04; Ord. No. O-16-09, § 3, 5-16-16) Sec. 54-34. - Posting of signs. (a) "No Smoking" signs or the international "No Smoking" symbol (consisting of a pictorial representation of a burning cigarette enclosed in a red circle with a red bar across it) shall be clearly and conspicuously posted in every building where smoking is prohibited by this article, by the owner, operator manager or other person having control of such building or area. (b) Every public place and every place of employment where smoking is prohibited by this article shall have posted at every entrance a conspicuous sign clearly stating that smoking is prohibited. (c) Notice of the provisions set forth in this article shall be given to all applicants obtaining an occupational tax certificate or professional license in the city. (Ord. No. O-04-13, 7-1-04) Sec. 54-35. - Employers' responsibility. It is the responsibility of employers to provide a smoke-free workplace for all employees of public places and places of employment. (Ord. No. O-04-13, 7-1-04) Sec. 54-36. - Penalty for violation of article. (a) Any person who violates any provision of this article shall be punished, upon conviction, as provided in section 1-12. (b) Any person who owns, manages, operates or otherwise controls a public place or a place of employment and who upon notice from any person authorized to enforce this article, knowingly violates any provision of this article shall be punished, upon conviction, as provided in section 1-12. (Ord. No. O-04-13, 7-1-04) Sec. 54-37. - Enforcement of article. (a) Any police officer, as defined by Georgia law, may issue a citation for any violation of this article. (b) The designated fire marshal of the city may issue a citation for any violation of this article. (c) Any designated codes enforcement officer, building inspector, building official or fire inspector of the city may issue a citation for any violation of this article. (Ord. No. O-04-13, 7-1-04) Secs. 54-38—54-55. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - UNSANITARY OR DANGEROUS PREMISES[3]
Footnotes: --- (3) --- State Law reference— Ordinances relating to repair, closing and demolition of dwellings unfit for human habitation or buildings or structures that imperil health, safety or morals, O.C.G.A. § 36-61-11; nuisances, O.C.G.A. § 41-1-1 et seq.; authority to demolish structures where drug crimes are committed, O.C.G.A. § 41-2-7; authority to repair, close or demolish unfit buildings or structures, O.C.G.A. § 41-2-7; county or municipal ordinances relating to unfit buildings or structures, O.C.G.A. § 41-2-9 et seq.
Sec. 54-56. - Prohibited conditions. It shall be unlawful for the owner or occupant of any property within the city to maintain such property with weeds, briars, vines, dead limbs, and branches from trees, underbrush, garbage, trash or other things thereon that will constitute an unsanitary or dangerous condition, health menace or fire hazard. (Code 1967, § 16-35(a); Ord. No. O-91-21, 11-4-91; Ord. No. O-92-06, 3-16-92) Sec. 54-57. - Storage of abandoned vehicles and junk. It shall be unlawful for the owner or occupant of any property within the city to utilize the premises of such property for the open storage of any abandoned motor vehicle, ice box, refrigerator, stove, appliance, glass, building material, building rubbish, or similar items that will constitute an unsanitary or dangerous condition, health menace or fire hazard. For the purposes of this section, an abandoned motor vehicle is defined as one that is in a state of disrepair and incapable of being moved under its own power. (Code 1967, § 16-35(b); Ord. No. O-91-21, 11-4-91; Ord. No. O-92-06, 3-16-92) Sec. 54-57.1. - Maintenance of graffiti. (a) "Graffiti" is defined according to O.C.G.A. § 17-15A-2 as "any inscriptions, words, figures, paintings, or other defacements that are written, marked, etched, scratched, sprayed, drawn, painted or engraved on or otherwise affixed to any surface of real property or improvements thereon without prior authorization of the owner or occupant of the property by means of any aerosol paint container, broad-tipped marker, gum label, paint stick, graffiti stick, etching equipment, brush or other device capable of scarring or leaving a visible mark on any surface." (b) It shall be unlawful for the owner or occupant of any property within the city to allow any graffiti that is visible from the street or other public or private property to remain upon any building, structure, appurtenance, equipment, any container used for storage of commercial refuse, recyclables or litter, or any fixed or portable box, container or storage unit, any sign, any surface, paving or similar feature located, installed, used or maintained on such property after the 15-day compliance period provided below. (Ord. No. O-08-03, 2-19-08) Sec. 54-58. - Unsecured vacant buildings. It shall be unlawful for the owner or person entitled to possession of any dwelling house, commercial or institutional building within the city to allow a vacant building to remain unsecured and open to the public for a period of ten or more days. Any such vacant building having broken, unlocked or missing doors or windows shall be deemed to be open to the public and to constitute a dangerous condition, health menace or fire hazard. (Code 1967, § 16-35(c); Ord. No. O-91-21, 11-4-91; Ord. No. O-92-06, 3-16-92) Sec. 54-59. - Failure to abate unlawful conditions after notice; violation of article. If the owner or occupant of any such property shall so maintain such property and shall fail to clean the premises or remove such items and/or graffiti as described in sections 54-56, 54-57 and 54-57.1, or if the owner or person entitled to possession of such vacant building as described in section 54-58 shall not close and secure such vacant building within 15 days after having been notified in writing by an official of the city public works department, fire department, or development department, such action on the part of the owner or occupant of the property shall constitute a violation of this article. A separate violation shall be deemed to occur for each and every day or portion thereof during which any violation of the requirements of this article is committed or continued. (Code 1967, § 16-35(d); Ord. No. O-91-21, 11-4-91; Ord. No. O-92-06, 3-16-92; Ord. No. O-08-03, 2-19-08) Sec. 54-60. - Notice contents; service. (a) Such written notice shall state what items or conditions constitute the graffiti, unsanitary or dangerous condition, health menace or fire hazard that must be cleared, removed or secured. (b) Service of such notice shall be as follows: (1) By delivery to the owner and occupant personally; (2) By registered or certified mail with postage prepaid deposited in the United States mail addressed to the owner's and occupant's last known address. (3) If service of notice cannot be accomplished by using the methods stated in subsections (b)(1) and (b)(2) of this section, by posting a copy of the notice in a conspicuous place on the premises. (Code 1967, § 16-35(e), (f); Ord. No. O-91-21, 11-4-91; Ord. No. O-92-06, 3-16-92; Ord. No. O-08-03, 2-19-08) Sec. 54-61. - Appeal of notice. Any person receiving written notice from an official designated in section 54-59 of deficiencies in his property under this article may, within 15 days following the date of such notice, enter an appeal in writing to the housing board of adjustments and appeals at city hall. Such appeal shall state the location of the property and the date of the notice of violations. The appeal must state the reasons upon which the appeal is made. Such appeal shall be heard and determined according to the provisions of section 106, housing board of adjustments and appeals, of the Southern Standard Housing Code, 1973 edition, as adopted by the city. (Code 1967, § 16-35(g); Ord. No. O-91-21, 11-4-91; Ord. No. O-92-06, 3-16-92) Sec. 54-62. - Citation for violation of article without further notice; conditions. Any person shall be considered to be in violation of this article and shall be subject to immediate citation without further notice if such person: (1) Has been found guilty of one violation of this article within the previous 12 months; and (2) Thereafter again, after the prior violation was cured, maintains the property on which the prior violation occurred in a manner described by sections 54-56, 54-57 and/or 54-58. (Code 1967, § 16-35(h); Ord. No. O-91-21, 11-4-91; Ord. No. O-92-06, 3-16-92) Sec. 54-63. - Report of violation; abatement procedure. In the event of a violation of this article, the city public works department, fire department or development department, may make a written report of its findings to the city commission with recommendation that the city have the premises cleaned and have removed therefrom such items as described in this article, that constitute an unsanitary or dangerous condition, health menace or fire hazard or, in the case of a building which is vacant, unsecured and open to the public, that the city close and secure the building. When such report with recommendations has been filed: (1) Placement on city commission agenda for hearing. The city commissioners shall have full power and authority, in their discretion, to place the matter upon their agenda for hearing at such time and place as the city commissioners may fix. (2) Service of report and notice to owner or occupant prior to hearing. A copy of the written report aforesaid and a written notice of the time and place fixed for hearing the matter shall be served upon the owner or occupant of such property at least 15 days prior to the date fixed for the hearing, such service to be made by the building official or other designated officer of the city in the manner specified in section 56-60. The hearing may be continued upon request of either party for reasonable cause. (3) Hearing; finding. The city commissioners shall hear the matter, including the response of such owner or occupant and witnesses introduced, and make their finding. (4) Abatement by city; lien; collection of lien. The city commissioners shall have the full power and authority to order that the offending premises be cleaned and/or secured and to authorize entry upon such premises for such purpose; to have graffiti removed or obliterated; to have the premises cleaned; and to have removed therefrom weeds, briars, vines, dead limbs, and branches from trees, underbrush, garbage, trash or other things thereon that will constitute an unsanitary or dangerous condition, health menace or fire hazard. In the case of a building which is vacant, unsecured and open to the public, the city commission shall have the building closed and secured, and assess the property for the cost of the cleaning, removal and/or closing and securing. Such assessment shall constitute a lien on the property until paid. An execution in favor of the city in the amount of such assessment shall be issued by the city clerk and bear attest in the name of the mayor or mayor pro-tem and be collected in accordance with the provisions of section 85 of the city Charter as set forth in this Code. (Code 1967, § 16-35(i); Ord. No. O-91-21, 11-4-91; Ord. No. O-92-06, 3-16-92; Ord. No. O-08-03, 2-19-08)

div.head: Chapter 62 - LAW ENFORCEMENT[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Alcoholic beverages, ch. 6; amusements and entertainments, ch. 10; animals, ch. 14; civil emergencies, ch. 30; emergency services, ch. 38; offenses and miscellaneous provisions, ch. 70; traffic and vehicles, ch. 98. State Law reference— Law enforcement officer appreciation day, O.C.G.A. § 1-4-6; peace officer memorial day and police week, O.C.G.A. § 1-4-7; authority to provide for police protection, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(1); Georgia Peace Officer Standards and Training Act, O.C.G.A. § 35-8-1 et seq.; training requirements for police chiefs, O.C.G.A. § 35-8-20; special policemen, O.C.G.A. § 35-9-1 et seq.; compensation of municipal law enforcement officers to be by fixed salary only, O.C.G.A. § 36-30-9; municipality's liability for torts of police or other officers, O.C.G.A. § 36-33-3; definition of police officer for purpose of state traffic laws, O.C.G.A. § 40-1-1; fleeing or attempting to elude police officers; impersonating law enforcement officer, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-395; assault under color of office, O.C.G.A. § 45-11-3; extortion generally, O.C.G.A. § 45-11-5; tort liability for false arrest, O.C.G.A. § 51-7-1 et seq.; tort liability for false imprisonment, O.C.G.A. § 51-7-20; tort liability for malicious prosecution, O.C.G.A. § 51-7-40; public officer causing arrest or detention for violation of O.C.G.A. § 45-11-1 not civilly liable, O.C.G.A. § 45-11-1(d).
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 62-1. - Cash bonds. (a) The chief of police, the captains of police and the desk sergeants of the police department of the city are hereby designated to accept cash bonds under the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 17-6-10, whereby designated officials of municipalities are authorized to accept cash bonds and to issue a receipt to the applicant for same. (b) All cash bonds so accepted shall be posted or accepted at the office of the police department in the city hall and at no other place, and likewise at the time such bond is so posted or accepted a receipt shall be issued at such office and at no other place. (Code 1967, § 2-10) Sec. 62-2. - Charge for furnishing information relative to police records. The chief of police is authorized to make a charge for furnishing information as to arrest records created by and in the custody of the police department. Such charges shall be as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges. (Code 1967, § 17½-1) Secs. 62-3—62-30. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - POLICE DEPARTMENT, IDENTIFICATION DIVISION
Sec. 62-31. - Penalty for violation of article. Any person who violates any provision of this article may, upon conviction, be punished by the provisions of section 1-12. (Code 1967, § 17½-30) Sec. 62-32. - Maintenance of identification and fingerprint division for certain persons. (a) The chief of police or his representative shall maintain an identification and fingerprint division within the police department of the city on the following persons: (1) Those persons arrested by the city police department and charged with a violation of a city ordinance or state or federal law. (2) Those persons engaged in the operation of cars for hire, and owners of same. (3) Those persons engaged in the operation or owners of a health club or reducing salon. (4) Those persons including, but not limited to, managers, shift managers and/or persons responsible for on-site supervision of the premises, who control the sale or service of any alcoholic beverage within the city limits in any store, restaurant or club or any other type of establishment. (b) A correct identification system shall be maintained with the fingerprints, photographs and personal history of those persons named in subsection (a) of this section. The records maintained in this section will be classified as "Temporary-Long term" as defined by the Georgia Secretary of State's Office — Archive Division and will be retained for at least the minimum time period required by the retention schedule published by the Georgia Secretary of State's Office — Archive Division. (Code 1967, §§ 17½-21, 17½-22; Ord. No. O-07-02, 1-17-07) Sec. 62-33. - Application by persons specified in section 62-32(4) to be fingerprinted and photographed; work permit required; contents, cost and renewal. Those persons in any way mentioned in section 62-32(4) shall, before engaging in any of the services mentioned, make application to the chief of police, for the purpose of being fingerprinted and photographed and shall have received a work permit which shall be valid for 12 months from the date of issue. This permit shall bear the name, date of birth, date of issue, person issuing the permit and a photograph of the applicant. The cost of this permit shall be as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges for the first year and for each additional year thereafter. The chief of police may deem it not necessary to refingerprint each applicant at the end of a 12-month period after a check of records, but a renewal permit will be required. (Code 1967, § 17½-23) Sec. 62-34. - Provisions of section 62-33 applicable to persons specified in section 62-32(2), (3). Those persons engaged in any way with section 62-32(2), (3) shall be governed by and issued work permits as provided in section 62-33. (Code 1967, § 17½-24) Sec. 62-35. - Permit to be kept on premises or in vehicle for hire; permits required under section 62-32(2) nontransferable. (a) Any permit issued by the chief of police for persons under section 62-32(2), (3) or (4) shall be kept on the premises where the applicant is employed or in the vehicle for hire, and shall be the property of the applicant unless revoked or expired. (b) Any permit issued under section 62-32(2) shall not be transferable to any other company for car or cars for hire. (Code 1967, § 17½-25) Sec. 62-36. - Revocation of permit; appeal from denial of permit. (a) Any and all permits issued by the chief of police shall be revoked by the chief of police, the mayor, or the city commission upon proof of any violations of this article, or any laws or ordinances of the city or any state or federal laws which are pertinent to the business covered by such permit. (b) Any person denied a permit for any of the purposes mentioned in this article may have the right to appeal to the city commission. (Code 1967, § 17½-26) Sec. 62-37. - Records to be used for purpose of law enforcement and licensing only. Any and all records maintained in the identification and fingerprint division shall be of use for the purpose of law enforcement and licensing only and shall not be a matter of public record. (Code 1967, § 17½-27) Sec. 62-38. - Right to review and challenge records. Any person having a record in the identification division of the city police department shall have the right to review any and all records maintained on the person, upon making written request to the chief of police, and then being fingerprinted and identifying himself to challenge the accuracy of such records. (Code 1967, § 17½-28)

div.head: Chapter 70 - OFFENSES AND MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Alcoholic beverages, ch. 6; amusements and entertainments, ch. 10; animals, ch. 14; civil emergencies, ch. 30; emergency services, ch. 38; health and sanitation, ch. 54; law enforcement, ch. 62; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 86; traffic and vehicles, ch. 98. State Law reference— Criminal Code of Georgia, O.C.G.A. § 16-1-1 et seq.; limitation on home rule powers of municipal corporations with respect to duplication of state criminal offenses, O.C.G.A. § 36-35-6(a)(2).
Sec. 70-1. - Penalty for violation of chapter. Any person guilty of a violation of any of the provisions of this chapter shall, upon conviction, be punished as provided by section 1-12. (Code 1967, § 16-36) Sec. 70-2. - Handbills, dodgers or commercial advertising notices—Distributing, throwing generally. It shall be unlawful to distribute to pedestrians upon any street, sidewalk, park or other public place in the city, or to distribute to passengers in any bus, or to throw into or upon any bus or automobile or other vehicle, any handbill, dodger or advertising notice of a commercial character. (Code 1967, § 3-2) Sec. 70-3. - Same—Depositing, distributing on private property. It shall be unlawful for any person to distribute or deposit any handbills, advertisements, printed matter or rubbish upon any real property located in the city without the consent of the owner thereof. (Code 1967, § 3-3) Sec. 70-4. - Same—Strewing on the streets or public places. No person shall strew about or cause to be strewn about in any street or public place, any circular, handbill, dodger or advertising notice of a commercial character. (Code 1967, § 3-4) Sec. 70-5. - Same—Signs restricting. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person engaged in the sale of merchandise, the taking of orders for any merchandise, the distribution of written materials or the solicitation of charitable contributions to disturb the peace of any occupant of any residential living unit by ringing the doorbell, knocking upon the door or otherwise attempting to attract the attention of the occupant when such residential living unit is properly labeled to forbid such conduct. (b) A residential living unit shall be properly labeled if a sign stating "No Soliciting" is placed on or about the door of the unit at a height of no less than 40 inches and no more than 66 inches from the bottom of the door and is either placed on the door or within 12 inches of either side of the door. The letters on such sign shall be a minimum of one-half inch high. (c) As an alternative, a residential living unit shall be deemed to be properly labeled if a sign stating "No Soliciting" is placed adjacent to the driveway, sidewalk or walkway leading to such residential living unit. A sign shall be deemed to be "adjacent" to the driveway, sidewalk or walkway if the nearest edge of the sign is no more than 12 inches from the driveway, sidewalk or walkway. Such sign shall be mounted at a height of no less than 12 inches and no more than 60 inches from the surface of the ground and the letters on such sign shall be a minimum of one inch high. (Code 1967, § 16-25) Sec. 70-6. - Failure to appear. It shall be unlawful for any person who has been served with a citation, accusation, summons, subpoena or other court document requiring that person's appearance in the municipal court for the city to fail to appear in municipal court on the date and at the time as set forth in such citation, accusation, summons, subpoena or other court document or fail to provide a satisfactory explanation for their absence. (Code 1967, § 1-8; Ord. No. O-15-13, §§ I, II,, 10-5-15) Sec. 70-7. - Escape from prison, jail or work gang. It shall be unlawful for any person, who has been convicted in the municipal court for the violation of any provision of this Code or any other ordinance of the city and sentenced to serve a term in the city prison or county jail, or to work on the streets of the city in the city work gang, to escape from such prison, jail or work gang. (Code 1967, § 18-1) Sec. 70-8. - Fortunetelling and related practices. From and after the adoption of this section, it shall be unlawful for any person to engage in or participate in the practice of fortunetelling, phrenology, clairvoyance, palmistry, or other kindred practices, businesses, or professions where a charge is made or a donation accepted for such services. (Code 1967, § 16-40; Ord. No. O-93-06, 7-6-93) Sec. 70-9. - Deposit of wastes on public or private property. It shall be unlawful for any person to place, deposit or permit the deposit of, in any unsanitary manner, human or animal excrement, garbage or objectionable wastes on any public or private property within the city. (Ord. No. O-90-16, 12-17-90) Sec. 70-10. - Fill dirt or fill material—Prerequisite to placing on property. It shall be unlawful for any fill dirt or fill material of any type to be placed upon any property within the corporate limits of the city unless same is rough graded, to five-tenths of a foot, within a period of 30 days following the placing of such fill dirt or fill material upon the property. (Code 1967, § 16-6.1) Sec. 70-11. - Same—To be free of glass, metal, construction debris and organic material. Any and all fill dirt or fill material so deposited upon any property within the corporate limits of the city shall be free of glass, metal, construction debris and organic materials. (Code 1967, § 16-6.2) Sec. 70-12. - Same—Responsibility of owner. It shall be the responsibility of the owner of such property upon which such fill dirt or fill material is placed to cause same to be rough graded to five-tenths of a foot within the 30-day period stated in section 70-10. (Code 1967, § 16-6.3) Sec. 70-13. - Firearms, air rifles and slingshots—Discharging in city. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person to fire or discharge any gun, pistol, cannon, air rifle or shoot a slingshot within the city; provided, however, that this section shall not apply to any police officer or other law enforcement officer who shall find it necessary to fire such weapon while in the discharge of his duties as such officer. (b) In the event of the conviction under this section of any person who is a minor, the chief of police shall seize and retain the firearm or other instrument until any fine and costs imposed by the municipal court judge are paid. (Code 1967, § 16-7) Sec. 70-14. - Iceboxes, refrigerators and other containers—Abandoning, discarding and leaving unattended without removing door or lock. It shall be unlawful for any person to leave in any place accessible to children any abandoned, unattended or discarded icebox, refrigerator or any other container of any kind which has an airtight door, or which has a lock which may not be released for opening from the inside thereof, without first removing such lock or door from such icebox, refrigerator or container. (Code 1967, § 16-14) State Law reference— Abandonment of containers which lock or fasten automatically, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-100. Sec. 70-15. - Ice cream or other edible products—Sale near schools. It shall be unlawful for any person to sell or offer for sale, within 250 yards of any public school building located in the city, between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m., any ice cream, milk, fruit or other edible products from a pushcart, truck or other conveyance, or by any means other than from a regularly established building or store duly licensed to operate such a business. (Code 1967, § 16-15) Sec. 70-16. - Knives and other dangerous implements. It shall be unlawful to have, possess or carry upon the streets, alleys or sidewalks of the city any of the following implements unless such implements are securely wrapped so as to be not readily available for harmful use: (1) Any knife which has a blade which opens automatically by hand pressure applied to a button, spring or other device in the handle, the blade of which when open projects from the handle more than two inches. (2) Any knife which has an obstruction or other device of any kind which holds the blade partly open, the blade of which when open projects from the handle more than two inches. (3) Any knife of any kind, the blade of which when open projects from the handle more than three inches, including all knives such as butcher knives or other knives which do not close. (4) Any razor. (5) Any icepick or similar device having a sharp point, provided that this subsection shall not apply to any person delivering ice. (Code 1967, § 16-17) Sec. 70-17. - Pistols, revolvers and derringers; sale of certain types. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, possess for sale, exhibit for sale, display or advertise for the purpose of sale, any .22 caliber pistol, revolver or derringer with a barrel three inches or less in length, which sells at a retail price of less than $39.00. (b) It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, to possess for sale, exhibit for sale, display or advertise for the purpose of sale, any pistol, revolver or derringer described in subsection (a) of this section, designed and manufactured to fire blank cartridges and ammunition containing explosive charges only, if such pistol, revolver or derringer may be adapted to fire cartridges and ammunition containing projectiles; provided, however, that this subsection shall not apply to any pistol, revolver or derringer to be used in any organized high school, college, professional or other recognized athletic events. (Code 1967, § 16-25.1) Sec. 70-18. - Disorderly conduct. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person within the corporate limits of the city to violate any of the following subsections of this section: (1) Any person who shall act in a violent or tumultuous manner toward another whereby any person is placed in danger of safety of his life, limb or health; (2) Any person who shall act in a violent or tumultuous manner toward another whereby the property of any person is placed in danger of being destroyed or damages; (3) Any person who shall cause, provoke or engage in any fight, brawl or riotous conduct so as to endanger the life, limb, health, or property of another; (4) Any person who shall assemble or congregate with another or others for the purpose or with the intent to engage in gaming; (5) Any person who shall frequent any public place with intent to obtain money from other persons by illegal and fraudulent schemes, tricks, artifices or devices; (6) Any person who assembles for the purpose of engaging in any fraudulent scheme, device or trick, to obtain any valuable thing in any place or from any person in the city, or who shall aid or abet therein; (7) Any person who shall use fighting words directed towards any person who becomes outraged and thus creates a turmoil; (8) Any person who shall by acts of violence interfere with another's pursuit of a lawful occupation; or (9) Any person who shall congregate with another or others in or on any public way so as to halt the flow of vehicular or pedestrian traffic and refuses to clear such public way when ordered by the city police or other lawful authority. (b) Any person who shall violate any subsection of this section may be charged with the offense of disorderly conduct and, on conviction thereof, may be found guilty of disorderly conduct. (Code 1967, § 16-38) Sec. 70-19. - Loitering or prowling. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person within the corporate limits of the city to commit the offense of loitering or prowling. (b) A person commits the offense of loitering or prowling when one is in a place, at a time, or in a manner not usual for law-abiding individuals under circumstances that warrant a justifiable and reasonable alarm or immediate concern for the safety of persons or property in the vicinity. State Law reference— Loitering or prowling, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-36. (c) Among the circumstances which may be considered in determining whether such alarm is warranted is the fact that the person takes flight upon the appearance of a law enforcement officer, refuses to identify himself, or manifestly endeavors to conceal himself or any object. Unless flight by the person or other circumstances makes it impracticable, a law enforcement officer shall, prior to any arrest for an offense under this section, afford the person an opportunity to dispel any alarm or immediate concern which would otherwise be warranted by requesting the person to identify himself and explain his presence and conduct. No person shall be convicted of an offense under this section if the law enforcement officer failed to comply with the foregoing procedure, or if it appears at trial that the explanation given by the person was true and would have dispelled the alarm or immediate concern. (d) A person committing the offense of loitering or prowling shall be guilty of a violation of this section and, upon conviction, shall be punished as provided in section 1-12. (Code 1967, § 16-43) Sec. 70-20. - Vehicle repair and towing operations. (a) It shall be unlawful for a business engaged in the major repair of automobiles, trucks, buses, trailers, boats, engines, motors, recreational vehicles, farm tractors and machines, and all other motorized and towed vehicles and parts thereof to park, store, or repair such vehicles and parts anywhere within the corporate limits of the city except in an enclosed building whose doors shall be kept tightly shut during painting and storage of vehicles and parts, or in an area which is screened by an opaque fence, wall or landscaped buffer at least six feet in height. Such fence, wall or buffer shall be maintained in good condition at all times. (b) It shall be unlawful for a business engaged in the towing and storage of automobiles, trucks, buses, trailers, boats, engines, motors, recreational vehicles, farm tractors and machines, and all other motorized and towed vehicles and parts thereof to park or store such vehicles and parts anywhere within the corporate limits of the city except in an enclosed building whose doors shall be kept tightly shut during storage of vehicles and parts, or in an area which is screened by an opaque fence, wall or landscaped buffer at least eight feet in height. Such fence, wall or buffer shall be maintained in good condition at all times. (c) It shall be unlawful for a business engaged in the minor repair of automobiles, trucks, buses, trailers, boats, motors, recreational vehicles, farm tractors and machines, and all other motorized and towed vehicles and parts thereof to repair such vehicles and parts in an area adjacent to or within 150 feet of a residential zoning district unless such area is screened from the residential zoning district by an opaque fence, wall or landscaped buffer at least six feet in height. Such fence, wall or buffer shall be maintained in good condition at all times. (d) For the purposes of subsection (a) of this section, the term "major repair" shall include such activities as painting or spray painting; repair to body, fender, bumper, clutch, transmission, differential, axle, spring, or similar part; overhaul or repair of engine requiring removal of cylinder head or crankcase pan; repair of radiator requiring removal from vehicle; recapping and retreading of tires; or similar activities. (e) For the purposes of subsection (c) of this section, the term "minor repair" shall include such activities as engine tune-up; servicing of spark plugs, batteries, distributors and similar items; replacement of mufflers, tail pipes, water hose, fan belts, brake fluid, light bulbs, fuses, floor mats, seat belts, seat covers, windshield wipers and blades, grease retainers, wheel bearings, mirrors and similar items; cleaning and flushing of radiators; repair or replacement of fuel pumps and lines; minor servicing or repair of carburetors; minor repairs to electrical system; minor adjustment of motors not involving removal of head or crankcase or racing motors; or similar activities. (Code 1967, § 16-44) Sec. 70-21. - Provisions saved from repeal. Section 16-39 relating to outdoor storage and processing and section 16-42 relating to open storage of materials are not repealed and shall continue in full force and effect pending a revision of the subject matter by the city commission. Sec. 70-22. - Public drunkenness. It shall be unlawful for any person to be and appear in an intoxicated condition, by alcoholic beverages or drugs, in any public place or any place accessible to the public, or within the curtilage of any private residence not his own other than by invitation of the owner or lawful occupant, which condition is made manifest by boisterousness, or by indecent condition or act, or by vulgar, profane, loud, or unbecoming language. (Code 1967, § 16-16.1) Sec. 70-23. - Keeping a disorderly place. Keeping a disorderly place is unlawful and is the intentional maintaining of any place where disturbances and illegal activities occur in a habitual or regular manner in means that disturb or alarm the neighborhood. Among the circumstances which may be considered in determining violation of this section are frequency of citizen complaints, prior warning to the person to curtail illegal activities on the premises, frequency of arrests, investigations or calls for police services at the location. No person shall be found guilty of this section unless he is an occupant of the place or maintains the place in question. (Code 1967, § 16-4) Sec. 70-24. - Loitering for purposes of engaging in drug-related activity. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person to loiter in or near any thoroughfare, place open to the public, or near any public or private place in a manner and under circumstances manifesting the purpose to engage in drug-related activity contrary to any of the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 16-13-1 et seq. (b) Among the circumstances which may be considered in determining whether such purpose is manifested are: (1) Such person is a known unlawful drug user, possessor, or seller.
