State Law reference— Obstructing sidewalks or other public passages, O.C.G.A. § 16-11-43; damaging public property, O.C.G.A. § 16-7-25; Georgia Code of Public Transportation, O.C.G.A. § 32-1-1 et seq.; governmental authorization by any county or municipality for construction or maintenance of any private road unlawful, O.C.G.A. § 32-1-8; state, county and municipal road systems, O.C.G.A. § 32-4-1 et seq.; powers with respect to municipal street system, O.C.G.A. § 32-4-92; regulation of maintenance and use of public roads generally, O.C.G.A. § 32-6-1 et seq.; grant by municipal corporation of right to obstruct public street prohibited, O.C.G.A. § 36-30-10; municipalities may permit enclosure of lanes or alleys, O.C.G.A. § 36-30-11; power of city to open, close or extend public streets, alleys and sidewalks, O.C.G.A. § 36-34-3; municipal street improvements, O.C.G.A. § 36-39-1 et seq.; power to construct and maintain roads, including curbs, sidewalks, street lights and devices to control the flow of traffic, Ga. Const. art. IX, § II, ¶ III(a)(4); executions for collection of municipal assessments for paving streets and laying sewers, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-358.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 86-1. - Penalty for violation of chapter. Any person guilty of a violation of this article shall be punished, upon conviction, as provided in section 1-12. (Code 1967, § 20-19) Sec. 86-2. - Property owners to keep sidewalks and/or pedestrian rights-of-way clean. (a) It shall be the duty of all property owners to keep sidewalks, and/or pedestrian rights-of-way on all sides of their property clean and free of papers, cups and waste of any kind on any day except refuse collection day. If the property is leased to a tenant, then the tenant shall be responsible for keeping sidewalks and/or pedestrian right-of-way clean. Upon being notified by a codes enforcement officer of any dirty condition of such sidewalks and rights-of-way the property, the owner or tenant shall be given seven days to clean such sidewalks or rights-of-way. (b) The codes enforcement officer, public works director and his/her designees, and the city engineer and his/her designees are hereby authorized, empowered and directed to enforce compliance with this article. (Ord. No. O-05-13, 8-1-05) Editor's note— Ord. No. O-05-13, adopted August 1, 2005, repealed the former § 86-2, and enacted a new § 86-2 as set out herein. The former § 86-2 pertained to duty of merchants to keep streets and sidewalks clean and derived from Code 1967, § 20-1. Sec. 86-3. - Merchants, or others to keep produce, fruits or merchandise off sidewalks. It shall be unlawful for any merchant or individual offering for sale any kind of produce, fruits or merchandise, to put the same in front of their respective places of business or premises on the sidewalks, excepting mobile food facilities where allowed as a limited use and where such activities do not conflict with standards set forth by the city. (Code 1967, § 20-2; Ord. No. O-17-04, § 1.1, 5-15-17) Sec. 86-4. - Sidewalks not to be obstructed for more than 30 minutes. No obstructions shall be placed on any sidewalks in the city for a period exceeding 30 minutes, excepting mobile food facilities where otherwise allowed as a limited use and where such activities do not conflict with standards set forth by the city. (Code 1967, § 20-3; Ord. No. O-17-04, § 1.2, 5-15-17) Sec. 86-5. - Protection of streets and sidewalks from accumulation of dirt. All persons who own real estate in the city which abuts on any of the streets and/or sidewalks of the city which are paved shall be required to sod the banks or earth abutting such paved streets and/or sidewalks with grass, or by other means, and to further protect by proper drainage all property so as to prevent washing or in other ways allowing dirt from abutting property to wash and accumulate on the street and/or sidewalk. (Code 1967, § 20-5; Ord. No. O-05-13, 8-1-05) Editor's note— Ord. No. O-05-13, adopted August 1, 2005, repealed the former § 86-5 and renumbered § 86-6 to read as § 86-5. The former § 86-5 pertained to property owners to keep sidewalks clean and derived from Code 1967, § 20-4. Sec. 86-6. - Reserved. Editor's note— See editor's note at § 86-5. Sec. 86-7. - Construction of certain curbs. All new curbs which are constructed in the city and all existing curbs which are part of any reconstruction, within any block, which is contiguous to any public street or highway and in which more than 15 percent of the territory is devoted to or zoned for business, commercial, industrial or multifamily residential use; in which any public educational institution is located; which curb is within any block that is adjacent to a block in which more than 15 percent of the territory is devoted to or zoned for business, commercial, industrial or multifamily residential use; or in which a public educational institution is located shall comply with this section. In order to enable persons using wheelchairs to travel freely and without assistance, at each crosswalk a ramp shall be built within a curb so that the sidewalk and street blend to a common level. Such ramp shall be not less than 32 inches wide and shall have a slope not greater than one inch rise per 12 inches length. Where because of surrounding buildings or other features of the terrain it is impossible to conform the slope with this section, the ramp shall contain a slope with as shallow a rise as possible under the circumstances. (Code 1967, § 20-6) Sec. 86-8. - Excavations; filling and compacting; lighting and barricading at night. It is hereby the duty of every plumber or other person making excavations in and upon the sidewalks or streets of the city for the purpose of making closet, sewer pipe or other connections, or making excavations on sidewalks or streets for any purpose whatever, after the completion of his work, to so fill and compact such excavations as to prevent the excavations or any portion thereof from sinking, caving or settling, so as to in any degree endanger or inconvenience pedestrians or vehicles passing thereover. Such filling and compacting shall be approved by city engineer. It is made the further duty of all persons making such excavations, until the excavation is pronounced safe by the city engineer, to place thereon and keep placed and lighted thereon between dark and daylight, a sufficient number of red lanterns or torches to warn the public, and in the day to fence or otherwise protect such excavations. (Code 1967, § 20-7) Sec. 86-9. - Opening and reconstruction of streets and sidewalks. After proper procedure, as set out in the ordinances governing such procedure has been complied with, and after the necessary authorization has been obtained for the opening or reconstruction of any old or new street, sidewalk or alley, it shall be unlawful for any person to enter upon the work and construct grading, draining, paving, curbing, sidewalks or any appurtenance or structure pertaining thereto without first submitting plans and specifications in detail for such work to the city engineer and seeking approval on the type, size, dimensions and kind of materials to be used in such construction and the grades and elevations of such new or old construction or reconstruction. The city engineer may withhold such approval until the constructing party has met the minimum requirements of the standard specifications of the city in use at the time, relating to such construction, and he may appoint representatives to enter upon the work during the construction thereof to see that the requirements of the city are fully complied with. (Code 1967, § 20-8) Sec. 86-10. - Contractors and other persons building or repairing shall place red lights around obstructions on streets and sidewalks at night. Whenever any contractor or other person is building or repairing buildings in the city and has material of any kind piled on the sidewalks or streets, it shall be the duty of the contractor, builder or other person to place red lights or torches around such obstructions at night in sufficient numbers to warn pedestrians and other people on such streets. (Code 1967, § 20-9) Sec. 86-11. - Driveway requirements. (a) Permit. It shall be unlawful for any property owner, lessee or tenant to construct or cause to have constructed a driveway entering upon a city street without first obtaining a permit for such work. (b) Other construction requirements. When such permit is issued the owner, lessee, tenant or other constructing party shall conform to all requirements of the standard specifications of the city in use at the time for that portion of the driveway from the curb or gutter line to the property line. Such constructing parties shall conform to all grades established and other special requirements as may be set out at the time by the city engineer or his duly authorized representative. (c) Surface. It shall be unlawful for any property owner, lessee or tenant to maintain within the city any driveway opening onto the sidewalks or streets of the city unless such driveway is covered with chert, stone, concrete, brick, or some similar material that will prevent dirt from such property from washing on the sidewalk or street. If such covering does not prevent dirt from such property washing onto the sidewalk or street, the sidewalk or street at such place shall be kept free of all dirt or washings by such owner, lessee or tenant. (d) Removal of dirt or washings; responsibility. It shall be unlawful for any such property owner, lessee or tenant to fail to remove such dirt or washings within 24 hours after the same has been deposited upon the street or sidewalk and after the attention of such owner, lessee or tenant has been called thereto. Where a driveway is joint, all of such joint owners, lessees or tenants shall be liable for any noncompliance with the provisions of this section. (Code 1967, § 20-10) Sec. 86-12. - Entrances and exits to public streets. (a) Approval required. All entrances and/or exits of any street or drive from or to any public street shall be approved by the city manager or his designated representative prior to the construction of the street or drive or to the issuance of any building permit for any improvement to be served by such street or drive. (b) Items to be considered in approval or disapproval. The following items shall be considered in approving or disapproving entrances and exits to public streets: (1) The width of proposed entrance or exit. Unless approved by the city manager, the maximum width of curb cuts, not including flares or returns at the throat of the facility, for entrances, exits, service drives and similar facilities shall be as follows: a. Commercial and industrial developments, including offices, retail establishments, banks, restaurants, warehouses, manufacturing and similar developments, 40 feet. b. Attached single-family residences, multiple-family residential and institutional developments, including apartment buildings, churches, schools, colleges, hospitals and similar developments, 24 feet for two-way entrances and 12 feet for one-way entrances. c. Single- and two-family residences and townhouses, 12 feet. (2) The distance of proposed entrance or exit to an existing intersection, to any property line, and/or to any existing or proposed entrance or exit to any existing or proposed street or drive. Except for a single-family residence, two-family residence or townhouse residence, entrances and exits shall be a minimum of 50 feet from the right-of-way line of any existing or proposed intersection, 40 feet from any existing or proposed curb cut, and 20 feet from any existing or proposed property line, unless approved by the city manager. (3) The number of proposed entrances and exits. (4) The suitability of the proposed entrance and exit in view of the use and development of adjacent and nearby property. (5) The suitability of the proposed entrance and exit in view of the amount of traffic on adjacent and nearby streets and the amount of traffic expected from the proposed development. (6) The suitability of the proposed entrance and exit in view of the impact on the public health, safety and welfare of the community. (c) Appeals. All persons denied an entrance or exit to a public street by decision of the city manager shall have the right to appeal such decision to the city commission. Such appeal shall be made within 15 days of the date of notice of such decision, shall be in writing, shall state the location of the subject property, the date of the decision being appealed and the reasons upon which the appeal is made. (Code 1967, § 20-10.1; Ord. No. O-17-09, §§ 1.1—1.4, 6-19-17) Sec. 86-13. - Reserved. Editor's note— Ord. No. O-17-03, § 2, adopted March 29, 2017, repealed § 86-13, which pertained to telegraph and telephone poles and derived from the Code of 1967, § 20-11. Sec. 86-14. - Work in the public streets and rights-of-way—Permit and bond required. (a) Any person desiring to make any improvement or perform other work in any public street or right-of-way of the city shall make an application for a permit for such work to the city engineer or his designee and shall deposit a sum not to exceed $500.00 as a bond to guarantee the replacement or repair of the street or right-of-way to the same condition as it was prior to the improvement or other work. The amount of the bond shall be determined by the city engineer or his designee according to the nature and extent of the work proposed. (b) For the purposes of this section, the expression "work in the public streets and rights-of-way" shall include but not be limited to, utility connections, including water, sewer, gas, electrical, telephone, cable television and/or other connections or taps to any water main, sewer, or other utility or service line, any curb, wall, walkway, drive or other work or improvement therein of any nature, but shall not include activities by utilities governed by Article VII of this Chapter 86. (c) When work on any public street or right-of-way takes place by any person for any of the purposes set out in section 84-14(b), such street or right-of-way shall be repaired and placed in the same condition as it was prior to the work within seven days of the start of such work. If the repairs required by this section are not completed within such time, the city engineer may make such repairs, deducting the cost thereof from the bond deposited as a guaranty and refunding the amount of deposit remaining, if any. (Code 1967, §§ 20-12, 20-13; Ord. No. O-90-08, §§ 1, 2, 6-4-90; Ord. No. O-17-03, § 3, 3-29-17) Sec. 86-15. - Same—Refunding of deposit. Subject to the provisions of section 86-14(c), the bond required by section 86-14(a) as a guaranty shall remain on deposit for a period of 30 days after the work on the public street or right-of-way is completed, and then shall be refunded to the depositor, provided that the repairs to the street or right-of-way have been properly made. (Code 1967, § 20-14; Ord. No. O-90-08, § 3, 6-4-90) Sec. 86-16. - Hauling dirt, soil, sand, rubbish, or other material. It shall be unlawful for any person to haul or transport for any distance, any dirt, soil, sand, rubbish or other material, over or upon or in the streets or sidewalks of the city, in any wagon, cart, wheelbarrow, truck or other vehicle from which such dirt, soil, sand, rubbish or any like substance escapes or leaks. (Code 1967, § 20-15) Sec. 86-17. - Wastewater—Allowing to run across sidewalk; when filling station premises may be washed. It shall be unlawful for any person within the city to allow wastewater from washing cars or from other sources to run across the sidewalk, and such person shall provide a cesspool or sewer to receive such water. Operators of filling stations may not wash their premises between the hours of 7:30 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. (Code 1967, § 20-16) Sec. 86-18. - Same—Using streets, sidewalks or gutters for drainage. It shall be unlawful for any person to use the streets, sidewalks or gutters as a means of drainage to carry off any used and dirty water or other filthy fluids. (Code 1967, § 20-17) Sec. 86-19. - Same—Discharging or throwing liquids from buildings so as to render street or sidewalk surface unsafe. It shall be unlawful for any person to throw or discharge from any lot or building any water, fluid or liquid substance so as to injuriously affect the surface of any city street or sidewalk so as to make it unsafe for travel. (Code 1967, § 20-18) Sec. 86-20. - Provisions saved from repeal. Section 14-16 of the 1967 Code requiring permits for parades and processions is not repealed and shall continue in full force and effect pending a revision of the subject matter by the city. Sec. 86-21. - Urban camping and improper use of public spaces. (a) Definitions. (1) Camp shall mean residing in or using a public street, sidewalk or park for private living accommodations, such as erecting tents or other temporary structures or objects providing shelter; sleeping in a single place for any period of time exceeding 60 minutes; regularly cooking or preparing meals; or other similar activities. (2) Storing personal property shall mean leaving one's personal effects, such as, but not limited to, clothing, bedrolls, cookware, sleeping bags, luggage, knapsacks or backpacks unattended for any period of time exceeding one hour. This term shall not include parking a bicycle or other mode of transportation. (3) Public park includes all municipal parks, public playgrounds, public plazas, attractions and monuments. (4) Public street includes all public streets and highways, public sidewalks, public benches, public parking lots and medians. (b) Public parks. It shall be unlawful to camp or to store personal property in any park owned by the city. (c) Public streets. It shall be unlawful to camp, to store personal property or to sit or to lie down on any public street as defined above. (d) Other public property blocking ingress and egress. It shall be unlawful to camp, to store personal property or to sit or to lie down on any public property so as to interfere with ingress or egress from buildings. (e) Warning. No person may be arrested for violation of this section until he or she has received a written warning and has been given an opportunity to cease the unlawful conduct. If, after receiving such warning and opportunity, a person fails to comply with the warning, he or she is subject to arrest for violation of this section. (f) Exceptions. Notwithstanding anything in this section to the contrary, this section shall not apply to nor be construed to prohibit the following behavior: (1) Persons sitting or lying down as a result of a medical emergency; (2) Persons sitting in wheelchairs while using parks, sidewalks or other public places; (3) Persons sitting down while attending parades for which valid permits have been issued; (4) Persons sitting down while patronizing outdoor cafes; (5) Persons sitting down, lying down or napping while attending performances, festivals and concerts taking place in any park, street or sidewalk; (6) Persons sitting on chairs or benches supplied by a public agency or abutting private property owner; (7) Persons sitting on seats in bus zones occupied by people waiting for the bus; (8) Persons sitting or lying down while waiting in an orderly line outside a box office to purchase tickets to any sporting event, concert, performance, other special event; (9) Persons sitting or lying down while waiting in an orderly line awaiting entry to any building, including shelters, or awaiting social services, such as provision of meals; or (10) Children under the age of 13 years sleeping in parks, or sleeping anywhere else while being carried by an accompanying person or while sitting or lying in a stroller or baby carriage. (11) Persons operating mobile food facilities, where allowed as a limited use and where such activities do not conflict with standards set forth the by the city. (Ord. No. O-97-20, 6-16-97; Ord. No. O-17-04, § 1.3, 5-15-17) Sec. 86-22. - Downtown Decatur Streetscape Design Guidelines. The Downtown Decatur Streetscape Design Guidelines shall be used to design streetscape improvements in the C-2 General Commercial Zoning District. The Downtown Decatur Streetscape Design Guidelines are a part of this section and have the same force and effect as if they were all fully set forth or described herein, and shall be properly attested and kept on file with then city clerk of the city. (Ord. No. O-99-03, 3-15-99) Sec. 86-23. - Regulation of publication vending devices. (a) Definitions. As used in this section, the following terms shall have the following meanings: Person: Any individual, firm, partnership, cooperative, nonprofit membership corporation, joint venture, association, company, corporation, agency, syndicate, estate, trust, business trust, receiver, fiduciary, or other group or combination acting as a unit, body politic, or political subdivision, whether public, private, or quasi-public. Publication vending device: Any self-service or coin-operated box, container, storage unit or other dispenser installed, used or maintained for the display, distribution or sale of publications, newspapers, periodicals, magazines or similar items. Street: All that area dedicated to public use for public transportation purposes and shall include, but not be limited to, roadways, alleys and sidewalks. Roadway: That portion of a street improved, designed or ordinarily used for vehicular travel. Public sidewalk: Any surface provided for the use of pedestrians, on any public right-of-way under the jurisdiction of the city. Publication vending device area: An area of the public sidewalk or other public right-of-way that has been determined by the city commission to be a suitable location for the installation and maintenance of publication vending devices. (b) Blocking of roadway; placement on sidewalks. (1) No person shall install, place or maintain any publication vending device which projects onto, into or over any part of the roadway of any public street, or which rests, wholly or in part, upon, along or over any portion of the roadway of any public street. (2) No person shall install, place or maintain any publication vending device which in whole or in part rests upon, in, or over any public sidewalk, when such installation, use or maintenance endangers the safety of persons or property; or, when such site or location is used for public utility purposes, public transportation purposes or public safety purposes; or, when such publication vending device unreasonably interferes with or impedes the flow of pedestrian or vehicular traffic, including any legally parked or stopped vehicle or the ingress into or egress from any residence or place of business. (3) No person shall install, place or maintain any publication vending device outside of the assigned publication vending device area. (c) Permit. (1) No person shall install, place or maintain any publication vending device which in whole or in part rests upon, in or over any public sidewalk without first obtaining a permit from the city manager or his/her designee. (2) An administrative fee shall be required for the issuance of a publication vending device permit in an amount set by the city manager. (3) Applications for all permits shall be in writing and must contain the following information: a. The name, address and telephone number of the applicant to include the address at which the applicant will receive notices as provided through the United States Postal Service and the telephone number to which any notice of repairs or complaints can be directed; and b. The total number of, and exact location of, each publication vending device to be installed or maintained in the city by the applicant; and c. An indemnification and hold harmless agreement. (4) Only one permit shall be required for the placement of any number of publication vending devices by one person, to the extent each location has been listed on the permit application submitted by such person. (5) Each person is allowed to maintain a maximum of three publication vending device locations. (6) A permit is valid for one year from date of issue. (7) A permit shall be granted if the application contains the required information and if the requested installation does not violate the prohibitions set forth in section (b) above and in section (d) below. (8) Denial of a permit shall be provided in writing listing the reason or reasons for denial. (9) The applicant shall be given notice of the opportunity to appeal the denial of a permit in writing to the city manager or his/her designee. The written appeal must include specific information as to why the permit should not be denied and must be filed within 30 days of the date of the notice of the denial of the permit. In considering an appeal, the city manager or his/her designee will apply the standards as described in section (b) above and in section (d) below. (d) Standards for installation, maintenance and operation. Any permitted publication vending device which in whole or in part rests upon, in or over any public sidewalk shall comply with the following standards: (1) Any person granted a publication vending device permit shall have his, her, or its name, address, telephone number, and permit number affixed to each publication vending device in a place where such information may be easily located and recognized. (2) No publication vending device shall exceed 42 inches in height, 30 inches in width and 24 inches in depth. All publication vending devices shall provide for an enclosed, secure and weatherproof area for the storage of publications, newspapers, periodicals, magazines or similar items during the time they are provided for display, distribution or sale. The publication vending device must be on the approved list of publication vending devices maintained in the city manager's office. (3) Publication vending devices shall be placed adjacent to the wall of a building, parallel to such wall and not more than six inches from the wall. (4) No publication vending device shall be chained, bolted or otherwise attached to any property without the permission of the owner or person in possession of the property. (5) No publication vending device shall be chained, bolted or otherwise attached to any city property, including, but not limited to, the sidewalk, trees, benches, light poles, bicycle racks, or trash receptacles. (6) No publication vending device shall be placed, installed, used or maintained outside an assigned publication vending device area. (7) Each publication vending device shall be maintained in a clean, neat and attractive condition and in good repair at all times. (e) Removal of publication vending device. (1) The city shall cause to be removed any publication vending device on any street or sidewalk in a location in violation of this section. Any publication vending device causing a traffic hazard or other hazard or illegally placed shall be removed at once, with notice given to the owner as soon as practical thereafter. The owner of any such publication vending device shall be assessed the costs for removing the rack as well as any storage costs. The costs shall be satisfied before the publication vending device is released to the owner. The city shall not retain such publication vending devices for more than 30 calendar days. (2) If a publication vending device is found in a state of disrepair the city will notify the owner via certified United States mail and notice on the machine that the device must be repaired within ten days of notification. (3) Any publication vending device which has been in disuse for at least 30 days shall be considered abandoned and will be subject to removal as described in subsection (e) above. (Ord. No. O-03-11, 1-1-04; Ord. No. O-04-02, 1-21-04; Ord. No. O-09-12, 11-2-09) Sec. 86-24. - Regulation of mobile food facilities. (a) Definitions. As used in this section, the following terms shall have the following meanings: Operation area : The amount of area needed to operate a particular mobile food facility, including both the amount of area occupied by the mobile food facility and an amount of area adjacent to the mobile food facility reasonably sufficient for an individual to operate the mobile food facility. Person: Any individual, firm, partnership, cooperative, nonprofit membership corporation, joint venture, association, company, corporation, or other group or combination acting as a unit, whether public, private, or quasi-public. Mobile food facility: A non-motorized, non-self-propelled vehicle that is readily movable or towable and that is commercially-designed to handle food preparation and service from which food or beverage is sold or offered for sale directly to a consumer. Street: All that area dedicated to public use for public transportation purposes and shall include, but not be limited to, roadways, alleys and sidewalks. Roadway: That portion of a street improved, designed or ordinarily used for vehicular travel. Public sidewalk: Any surface provided for the use of pedestrians, on any public right-of-way under the jurisdiction of the city. (b) Blocking of roadway; placement on sidewalks. (1) No person shall operate, place or maintain any mobile food facility which projects onto, into or over any part of the roadway of any public street, or which rests, wholly or in part, upon, or over any portion of the roadway of any public street. (2) No person shall operate, place or maintain a mobile food facility within a public sidewalk, in whole or in part, in a manner that endangers the safety of persons or property or that unreasonably interferes with or impedes the flow of pedestrian or vehicular traffic, including any legally parked or stopped vehicle or the ingress into or egress from any residence or place of business. (3) No person shall place a mobile food facility that reduces the clear zone of a public sidewalk to a width of less than five feet. (c) Permit. (1) No person shall operate, place or maintain any mobile food facility upon, in, within or over any public sidewalk or private property without first obtaining a permit from the city manager or his/her designee. (2) An administrative fee shall be required for the issuance of a mobile food facility permit in an amount set by the city commission. (3) Applications for all permits shall be in writing and must contain the following information: a. The name, address and telephone number of the applicant to include the address at which the applicant will receive notices as provided through the United States Postal Service and the telephone number to which any notice of complaints can be directed; and b. The dimensional height, width and length of the mobile food facility, and the location where the applicant proposes to operate the mobile food facility; and c. An indemnification and hold harmless agreement (sidewalk permits only); and d. An affidavit attesting that the applicant either has applied for or will immediately apply for the applicable permit for the operation of the mobile food facility from the DeKalb County Board of Health in accordance with its rules and regulations and certify that the proposed mobile food facility will meet and be operated in conformance with all applicable state laws and regulations, including the Georgia Department of Agriculture, county ordinances and regulations, and city codes and regulations. (4) If the city manager or their designee determines that an application to operate a mobile food facility is in compliance with the applicable requirements, the city manager or their designee shall approve the application for a permit, but the permit for operation shall not be issued until the applicant has obtained the applicable permit from the DeKalb County Board of Health. (5) Each person is allowed to operate a maximum of one mobile food facility in the city. (6) A permit is valid for one year from date of issue. (7) A permit shall be granted if the application contains the required information and if the requested operation does not violate the prohibitions set forth in section (b) above and in section (d) below. (8) Denial of a permit shall be provided in writing listing the reason or reasons for denial. (9) The applicant shall be given notice of the opportunity to appeal the denial of a permit in writing to the city manager or his/her designee. The written appeal must include specific information as to why the permit should not be denied and must be filed within 15 days of the date of the notice of the denial of the permit. In considering an appeal, the city manager or his/her designee will apply the standards as described in section (b) above and in section (d) below. (10) No permit for the operation a mobile food facility shall be transferable. (11) Permits may be revoked by the city commission for failure of the permittee to comply with the provisions of this section. (d) Standards for operation. Any permitted mobile food facility shall comply with the following standards: (1) Any person granted a mobile food facility permit shall have his, her, or its name, address, telephone number, valid city permit, and valid permit from the DeKalb County Board of Health affixed to the mobile food facility in a place where such information is easily visible to the customer. (2) A mobile food facility shall not exceed a maximum operation area of 36 square feet. (3) No such mobile food facility shall be operated, placed or maintained within ten feet of any other mobile food facility, said distance to be measured in a straight line from the closet boundary of the operating area of a neighboring facility. (4) No mobile food facility shall be operated, placed or maintained within 50 feet of any primary entrance of any restaurant within the city. (5) No mobile food facility shall be operated, place or maintained within 20 feet of the intersection of the right-of-way lines extended of two streets or of a street intersection with a railroad right-of-way line. (6) No sale or serving of alcohol. (7) No sale to persons in vehicles. (8) No amplified sound or loudspeakers. (9) No lighting, except localized lighting that is used on or in the mobile food facility for the purpose of operating the mobile food facility. (10) Each mobile food facility shall be maintained in a clean, neat and attractive condition and in good repair at all times. (11) The on-site presence of an individual owner or employee during hours of operation is required. (e) Removal of mobile food facility. (1) The city shall cause to be removed any mobile food facility on any street or sidewalk in a location in violation of this section. Any mobile food facility causing a traffic hazard or other hazard or illegally placed shall be removed at once, with notice given to the owner as soon as practical thereafter. The owner of any such mobile food facility shall be assessed the costs for removal as well as any storage costs. The costs shall be satisfied before the mobile food facility is released to the owner. The city shall not retain such mobile food facility for more than 30 calendar days. (f) Hours of operation. Mobile food facilities shall only be operated, including sales, set up, take down, and removal, between 8:00 a.m. and 9:00 p.m. Monday through Thursday, between 9:00 a.m. and 10:00 p.m. Fridays and Saturdays, and between 9:00 a.m. and 8:00 p.m. Sundays. (Ord. No. O-17-04, § 1.4, 5-15-17) Secs. 86-25—86-45. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - UTILITY CONNECTIONS PRIOR TO PAVING OF STREETS
Sec. 86-46. - Penalty for violation of article. Any person found guilty of a violation of this article, upon conviction, shall be punished as provided in section 1-12. (Code 1967, § 20-26) Sec. 86-47. - Required; notice by chief of construction; subsequent disturbing of streets. It shall be the duty of the chief of construction, when any street of the city has been ordered paved or repaved by the mayor and city commission, to give notice to persons owning property on such street ordered paved or repaved requiring such owners to enter into the street and make all connections required for their property with pipes, conduits, or similar service furnished either by the city or public service corporations, for water, sewer, and gas connections, before the time at which such pavement is begun. Thereafter such pavement or public improvement shall not be disturbed for the purpose of laying pipes, conduits or connecting therewith, except by special permit of the mayor and city commission. (Code 1967, § 20-20) Sec. 86-48. - Notice provision; making of connections by city upon failure of property owner to begin work. The notice required in section 86-47 shall provide for the property owner to begin work on the connections referred to in such section within five days. If the work is not begun within such time, the city shall proceed to make such connections at the expense of such property owner. (Code 1967, § 20-21) Sec. 86-49. - Completion of work by city upon failure of property owner to do so. If any property owner begins work on any connections referred to in section 86-47 and fails and refuses to complete such work within a reasonable time, the city shall take up such work and complete it at the expense of such property owner. (Code 1967, § 20-22) Sec. 86-50. - Assessment of costs—Issuance of execution against property owner and property. Should it be necessary for the city to make any of the connections referred to in section 86-47, the city clerk shall render to each property owner a bill for the cost of such improvement, and, if such bill is not paid within ten days after receipt, the city clerk shall issue an execution against such property owner and against such property so improved for the cost of such improvement. (Code 1967, § 20-23) Sec. 86-51. - Same—Levy and sale of property. The executions issued under the provisions of section 86-50 shall be turned over to the marshal of the city who shall proceed to levy and sell the property so improved to satisfy such execution in the same manner as is provided by the Charter of the city for executions issued for street improvement and for the cost of laying sewers in the streets of the city. (Code 1967, § 20-24) Sec. 86-52. - Same—Right of property owner to file affidavit of illegality. Any property owner shall have the right to file his affidavit of illegality to any execution issued under the provisions of section 86-50, returnable to the county superior court, as provided by the Charter of the city to be done in the case of executions issued for street improvements of the city. (Code 1967, § 20-25) Secs. 86-53—86-75. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - RESERVED[2]

Secs. 86-76—86-100. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - NEIGHBORHOOD IMPACT STUDIES FOR MAJOR UTILITY PROJECTS
Sec. 86-101. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Major projects means any of the following: (1) Electrical transmission lines in excess of 100 kv. (2) New overhead lines by any utility where none presently exist, but not to include local service lines or service that is internal to a new residential development project. (3) New underground utility construction unless it is accomplished within existing public rights-of-way, is a local service line or is internal to a new residential development project. The adding of an additional cable in an existing underground conduit shall not constitute a major project. (4) Rapid transit facilities. Neighborhood impact study means a study and a written report on the effects on the residential neighborhood in which the major project is proposed, such study to be conducted by the utility proposing the project. Such study shall include an analysis of the effect on public health, safety, welfare and aesthetics; the consideration of alternative actions as to cost, feasibility and impact; and the consideration of ameliorating measures to be taken to reduce negative impacts on public health, safety, welfare and aesthetics. (Code 1967, § 20-37) Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Sec. 86-102. - Required. No permit shall be issued for the construction of a major project in areas zoned for residential use in the city, according to the official zoning map, until a neighborhood impact study has been completed and such study has been accepted as complete and accurate by the city commission. (Code 1967, § 20-38) Sec. 86-103. - Public inspection. Upon completion, a neighborhood impact study shall be filed with the city clerk and made available for public inspection. No action shall be taken by the city commission in approving or rejecting the study earlier than 15 days or later than 30 days after it is filed with the city clerk. (Code 1967, § 20-39) Sec. 86-104. - Acceptance or rejection of study. The city commission may accept the neighborhood impact study as being accurate and complete, or it may reject the study as not being accurate or complete. If the study is rejected by the city commission, the reasons for such rejection shall be specified, and the utility preparing the study shall have 15 days to respond. The city commission shall have 15 days to make a final determination. (Code 1967, § 20-40) Secs. 86-105—86-130. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - REQUIREMENTS FOR PARKING LOTS
Sec. 86-131. - Applicability; barrier curb and landscaping requirements. All surface parking lots within commercial C-2 zoning districts, with a total of 30 or more parking spaces, whether primary or accessory in use and whether commercial or noncommercial, shall have minimum barrier curb and landscaping requirements as follows: (1) Barrier curbs shall be installed around the perimeter of the parking lot and around landscaped areas that are required herein, except where the perimeter abuts an adjacent building or structure and at points of ingress and egress into the facility, so as to prevent encroachment of vehicles onto adjacent property, rights-of-way and landscaped areas. (2) Barrier curbs shall be a minimum of six inches in height and a minimum of eight inches in width and permanent in nature. Barrier curbs shall be concrete or stone. Such curbs shall be securely installed and maintained in good condition. (3) Where the end of a parking space abuts a landscaped area, barrier curbs may be placed in the parking space at a maximum of two feet from the end of the parking space. This two-foot-wide area may have the pavement removed and be developed as part of the required landscaped area. (4) Surface parking lots shall have a minimum landscaped area equal to at least ten percent of the paved area within such lot. In no case shall a parking lot owner be required to provide landscaped areas that exceed ten percent of the paved area. (5) A minimum of one tree per eight parking spaces shall be included in the required landscaped areas. For the purpose of satisfying this requirement, existing trees that are two and one-half inches or more in caliper as measured at a height of 36 inches above ground level shall be considered to be equivalent to one or more newly planted trees on the basis of one tree for each two and one-half inches of caliper. (6) In addition to trees, ground cover shall also be provided in order to protect tree roots and to prevent erosion. Ground cover shall consist of shrubs, ivy, liriope, pine bark mulch, and other similar landscaping materials. (7) Shrubs shall be maintained at a maximum height of two and one-half feet, except where such shrubs are screening the parking surface from an adjacent residential use. (8) In the event that landscaped areas are in the interior of a parking lot, they shall be a minimum of six feet in length with a minimum area of 36 square feet. (9) Continuous landscaped buffer strips shall be constructed along sidewalks and public rights-of-way where surface parking lots are adjacent to such sidewalks or public rights-of-way except at points of ingress and egress into the facility. Such landscaped buffer strips shall be a minimum of five feet in width and shall contain, in addition to ground cover, trees planted a maximum of 42½ feet on center along the entire length. (10) Newly planted trees shall be a minimum of two and one-half inches in caliper as measured at a height of six inches above ground level, shall be a minimum of ten feet in height, shall have a 40-foot minimum mature height, and shall be drought tolerant. Trees shall be planted at a minimum of 30 inches from any barrier curb, so as to prevent injury to trees from vehicle bumpers. (11) Where landscaped areas are located adjacent to vehicle overhangs, the trees shall be planted in line with the side stripes between parking spaces in order to avoid injury to trees by vehicle bumpers. (12) All landscaped areas, including trees located in the public right-of-way that are counted in the fulfillment of this requirement, shall be properly maintained in accordance with approved landscape plans. In the event that a tree or any plant material dies, it shall be replaced within six months so as to meet all requirements of this section and to allow for planting in the appropriate planting season. (13) If it is determined by the city arborist that implementation of these regulations will result in the loss of parking spaces in existing lots, the public works director may increase the allowable percentage compact car spaces from 25 percent up to 35 percent so as to minimize the loss of parking spaces. (14) Notwithstanding subsection (13) above, existing parking lots shall not be required to reduce the number of parking spaces by more than three percent as a result of implementing these landscaping regulations. (15) Upon written application by any person subject to the provisions of this section, the city manager and/or his/her designee is hereby authorized to grant administrative variances to the requirements of this section only upon making all of the following findings: a. There are extraordinary and exceptional conditions pertaining to the particular piece of property in question because of its size, shape, topography, subsurface conditions, overhead structures, or the existence of sufficient trees in the public right-of-way within ten feet of the property line; b. Such conditions are peculiar to the particular piece of property involved; and c. Relief, if granted, would not cause substantial detriment to the public good or impair the purposes and intent of this article. (Ord. No. O-95-06, 6-19-95) Secs. 86-132—86-149. - Reserved. ARTICLE VI. - SPECIAL EVENT PERMIT
Sec. 86-150. - Penalty for violation of article. Any person guilty of a violation of this article shall be punished, upon conviction, as provided in section 1-12. (Ord. No. O-96-10, 7-8-96) Sec. 86-151. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates another meaning: Permit fee means the charge required to be paid pursuant to this article for the issuance of a permit to hold a special event. Person means any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company or organization of any kind. Sanitation bond fee means the deposit, conditioned upon good performance, which shall be required of any applicant or sponsoring organization to ensure the cleaning of streets, public parks or public lands upon completion of a permitted special event. Special event means any parade, march, ceremony, demonstration, show, exhibition, pageant, athletic event or procession of any kind, or any similar display, in or upon any street, sidewalk, park or other public property, within the city limits, that interferes with the normal flow of traffic or use of public property by the public. Movement from one point to another is not a required element of a special event. Special event permit means a permit required by this article. (Ord. No. O-96-10, 7-8-96) Sec. 86-152. - Permit required. No person shall engage in, participate in, aid, form or start any special event unless a special event permit shall have been obtained from the office of the director of public safety. (Ord. No. O-96-10, 7-8-96) Sec. 86-153. - Exceptions. This article shall not apply to: (1) Funeral processions; (2) Students going to and from school classes or participating in school sponsored educational activities or athletic events, provided such conduct is under the immediate direction and supervision of the proper school authorities; (3) A public event which is directly related to a recognized function of city, state or local government and which is in a major part initiated, financed and executed by the city, state or local government, or subdivision of the state; (4) City block parties that have received a block party permit from the office of the city manager; and (5) Peaceful picketing in connection with labor disputes. (Ord. No. O-96-10, 7-8-96) Sec. 86-154. - Application for permit. A person seeking issuance of a special event permit shall file in writing an application with the office of the director of public safety on forms provided by the city. Such application shall be filed not less than 14 days nor more than 60 days before the date on which the proposed special event is to be conducted. (Ord. No. O-96-10, 7-8-96) Sec. 86-155. - Application contents. The application for a special event permit shall set forth the following information: (1) The name, address and telephone number of the person seeking to conduct the special event; (2) If the special event is to be conducted for, on behalf of, or by an organization, the name, address and telephone number of the headquarters of the organization, and of the authorized and responsible heads of such organization; (3) The name, address and telephone number of the person who will be the special event leader and who will be responsible for its conduct; (4) The name of the special event and its purpose; (5) The date when the special event is to be held; (6) The route to be traveled, the starting point and the termination point; (7) If a parade, the approximate number of persons, animals and vehicles which will constitute the parade, including the type of animals and description of vehicles; (8) The approximate number of spectators and participants that will attend or participate in any part of the special event. If the special event is to take place on more than one day, the approximate number of spectators and participants per day. If a spectator or participant is present for only a part of the special event, that person shall be included in the approximate number; (9) The hours when the special event will start and terminate; (10) A statement as to whether the special event will occupy all or only a portion of the widths of the streets proposed to be used; (11) If such a special event is to be held in a city park or other public area, a statement as to whether the special event will occupy all or only a portion of the area; (12) The location of any assembly areas for the special event; (13) The time at which units of the special event will begin to assemble at any assembly area; (14) A description of any public address or loudspeaker system to be used; (15) If the special event is designed to be held by, on behalf of, or for any person other than the applicant, the applicant for the permit shall file with the office of the director of public safety a communication in writing from the person proposing to hold the special event authorizing the applicant to apply for the permit on his/her behalf; (16) The estimated number of vehicles requiring parking at the special event; (17) Whether any temporary outdoor structures are proposed to be built, describing them in detail and their location; and (18) Such other information as the director of public safety or a designated representative may deem reasonably necessary. (Ord. No. O-96-10, 7-8-96) Sec. 86-156. - Late applications. The director of public safety or a designated representative, where good cause is shown, shall have the authority to consider any application which is filed less than 14 days before the date the special event is proposed to be held. (Ord. No. O-96-10, 7-8-96) Sec. 86-157. - Standards for issuance. The director of public safety shall issue a special event permit as provided for in this article when, from a consideration of the application and from such other information as may otherwise be obtained, it is determined: (1) The conduct of the special event will not substantially interrupt the safe and orderly movement of other traffic contiguous to its route or place of occurrence; (2) The conduct of the special event will not require the diversion of so great a number of police officers of the city to properly police the line of movement and the areas contiguous thereto as to prevent normal police protection to the city; (3) The concentration of persons, animals and vehicles at assembly points of the special event will not unduly interfere with proper fire and police protection of, or ambulance service to, areas contiguous to the assembly areas; (4) The conduct of the special event will not unreasonably interfere with the movement of firefighting equipment in route to a fire; (5) The conduct of the special event is not likely to cause injury to persons or property, to provoke disorderly conduct or to promote immediate lawless activity; (6) The special event is scheduled to move from its point of origin to its point of termination expeditiously and without unreasonable delays; (7) The information contained in the application is not found to be false or nonexistent in any material detail; and (8) The applicant agreed to abide by or comply with all conditions of the permit, in particular, the responsibility to clean all areas used. (Ord. No. O-96-10, 7-8-96) Sec. 86-158. - Time for action on application or notice of denial. The director of public safety or a designated representative shall act upon the application for a special event permit within five working days after the receipt thereof. The director of public safety or a designated representative shall deliver or mail to the applicant within five days after the date upon which the application was filed the special event permit or, if not approved, a notice of the action, stating reasons for the denial of the permit. If the application is incomplete, the director of public safety will state which parts of the application have not been completed. (Ord. No. O-96-10, 7-8-96) Sec. 86-159. - Appeal procedure. (a) Any person not receiving a special event permit shall have the right to appeal the denial of a permit to the city manager within ten working days after the denial was issued. The city manager or a designated representative shall hear the appeal within five working days of receipt of a request for an appeals hearing. The city manager shall review the manner in which the director of public safety evaluated the special event application with regards to the criteria set out in this article. The city manager shall either approve, deny, or amend the application within five days of the appeal hearing and deliver or mail the results to the applicant. (b) Any applicant denied a special events permit by the city manager shall be granted a hearing in the municipal court provided the applicant files a request in writing with the municipal court within ten days of receipt of notification by the city manager. The applicant shall notify the city manager in writing, by person or by mail, of the appeal within three days of filing an appeal with the municipal court. (c) The municipal court judge shall hear the appeal at the next available court session. The judge shall hear evidence as to the reasons the application was denied by the director of public safety and the city manager. The judge shall approve, disapprove, or amend the application. The judge shall notify the applicant of the decision within five working days after the hearing in municipal court, such notification being sent by registered mail. The decision of the municipal court judge is final. (Ord. No. O-96-10, 7-8-96) Sec. 86-160. - Alternative permit. The director of public safety or a designated representative, in denying an application for a special event permit, may authorize the conduct of the special event on a date, a time, or over a route different from that named by the applicant. An applicant desiring to accept an alternate permit shall within two days after notice of the action file a written notice of acceptance with the office of the director of public safety. An alternate permit shall conform to the requirements of, and shall have the effect of, a special event permit under this article. (Ord. No. O-96-10, 7-8-96) Sec. 86-161. - Notice to city and other officials. Immediately upon application for or issuance of a special event permit, the director of public safety or a designated representative shall send a copy thereof to the following: (1) The city manager; (2) The police chief; (3) The fire chief; (4) The director of public works; and (5) The city attorney. (Ord. No. O-96-10, 7-8-96) Sec. 86-162. - Contents of a special event permit. Each special event permit shall state the following: (1) Starting and ending time; (2) The route to be transversed; (3) The portions of the streets to be transversed that may be occupied; (4) The portions of any parks or public property to be occupied; (5) The maximum length of the special event; and (6) Such other information as the director of public safety or a designated representative shall find necessary to the enforcement of this article. (Ord. No. O-96-10, 7-8-96) Sec. 86-163. - Duties of special event permittee. (a) A permittee shall comply with all permit directions and conditions and with all applicable local, state and federal laws and ordinances. (b) The special event leader shall carry the special event permit upon his or her person during the conduct of the special event. (Ord. No. O-96-10, 7-8-96) Sec. 86-164. - Public conduct during special event. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person to hamper, obstruct, impede or interfere with any special event or with any person, animal or vehicle participating or used in a special event. (b) The director of public safety or a designated representative shall have the authority to prohibit or restrict the parking of vehicles along a roadway constituting a part of the route of a special event. When necessary, the police department shall post signs to the effect and it shall be unlawful for any person to park or leave unattended any vehicle in violation thereof. Police officers may cause to be impounded any vehicle unlawfully parked in violation of this article. (Ord. No. O-96-10, 7-8-96) Sec. 86-165. - Distribution of material during parade or procession prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to distribute or cause to be distributed from any vehicle participating in a parade or procession in the public streets any item to any spectator or bystander. (Ord. No. O-96-10, 7-8-96) Sec. 86-166. - Revocation of permit. The director of public safety or a designated representative shall have the authority to revoke a special event permit at any time during conduct of the special event in the event of failure to conform to or comply with the standards for issuance as set forth in section 86-156. The director of public safety or a designated representative may at any time revoke a parade permit when, by reason of disaster, public calamity, riot or other emergency, the safety of public or private property requires such revocation. (Ord. No. O-96-10, 7-8-96) Sec. 86-167. - Classification of permit and bond fees. (a) The director of public safety is authorized to classify the special event using the following criteria: (1) The anticipated amount of extra personnel which shall be required to be furnished by the city to accomplish the necessary public safety and sanitation components of the special event. By agreement, as endorsed upon the special event permit, the applicant may furnish some or all of the personnel requirements and the classification shall be considered and reduced accordingly; (2) The type and amount of special or technical assistance required from city employees; (3) The anticipated number of spectators and participants over the entire period of the special event, determined in accordance with section 86-155(h); and (4) Whether the organization(s) producing and/or sponsoring the special event is/are profit-making or nonprofit. (b) The classes of special event permits shall be as follows: (1) Class A permit: For a special event which will require between 100-200 extra staff hours by city employees in any department or in which the approximate number of spectators and participants, as determined in accordance with section 86-155(h), is 8,000 or more persons, and is being held by a profit-making organization. (2) Class B permit: For a special event which has the characteristics of a class A permit but which is organized and executed by a nonprofit organization. (3) Class C permit: For a special event which will require between 50-99 extra staff hours by city employees in any department or in which the approximate number of spectators and participants, as determined in accordance with section 86-155(h), is between 3,000 and 8,000 persons, and is being held by a profit-making organization. (4) Class D permit: For a special event which has the characteristics of a class C permit but which is organized and executed by a nonprofit organization. (5) Class E permit: For a special event which will require less than 50 extra staff hours by city employees in any department or in which the approximate number of spectators and participants, as determined in accordance with section 86-155(h), is 3,000 persons or less and is being held by a profit-making organization. (6) Class F permit: For a special event which has the characteristics of a class C permit but is organized and executed by a nonprofit organization. (c) The permit fee and the sanitation bond shall be as follows:
Any special event requiring in excess of the agreed upon city staffing hours shall be charged a prorated fee in addition to the initial base fee. Upon satisfactory completion of the sanitation bond agreement, the sanitation bond shall be refunded to the applicant. (Ord. No. O-96-10, 7-8-96) Sec. 86-168. - Indemnification agreement. Prior to the issuance of a special event permit, the permit applicant or a duly authorized officer of the sponsoring organization must sign an agreement to reimburse the city for any costs incurred in repairing damage to city property resulting from or in connection with a permitted event. The agreement shall also provide that the permittee or sponsoring organization shall defend the city against, and indemnify and hold the city harmless from, any liability to or claims of liability by any persons resulting from any alleged damage or injury occurring in connection with the special event. (Ord. No. O-96-10, 7-8-96) Sec. 86-169. - Insurance. The applicant or sponsoring organization must possess or obtain public liability insurance to protect against loss from liability imposed by law for damages on account of bodily injury and property damage arising from the special event. The insurance shall name on the policy as additional insured the city, its officers, employees and agents. Insurance coverage must be maintained for the duration of the event. A copy of the policy or a certificate of insurance along with all necessary endorsements must be filed with the city manager's office no later than seven days before the date of the special event. The minimum limit of insurance is $500,000.00. (Ord. No. O-96-10, 7-8-96) ARTICLE VII. - USE OF RIGHTS-OF-WAY BY UTILITIES
Sec. 86-170. - Intent and purpose. The city is vitally concerned with the use, construction within, and occupancy of all rights-of-way in the city as such rights-of-way are a valuable and limited resource which must be utilized to promote the public health, safety, welfare, and economic development of the city and to protect public work infrastructure. Therefore, the city, under the authority of the laws and Constitution of the State of Georgia, has adopted this article for the purpose of regulating public and private entities which use the city rights-of-way. (Ord. No. O-17-03, § 1, 3-29-17) Sec. 86-171. - Scope. The provisions of this article shall apply to all utilities and facilities occupying the rights-of-way as provided herein. (Ord. No. O-17-03, § 1, 3-29-17) Sec. 86-172. - Definitions. For the purposes of this article, the following terms, phrases, words, and their derivations have the meanings set forth herein, unless the context clearly indicates that another meaning is intended. Administrative standards means the written standards prepared by the city manager that contain additional application, technical and/or procedural requirements related to right-of-way permits that are applicable in the city of Decatur, at least including the latest editions of the GDOT "Utility Accommodation Policy and Standards" and the city "Right-of-Way Permit Standards for utilities;" Code means the Code of Ordinances of the city of Decatur, Georgia; Construct means, but shall not be limited to, dig, bore, tunnel, trench, excavate, obstruct, install or remove signs, or facilities, other than landscaping or ornamental plantings, in, on, above, within, over, below, under, or through any part of the rights-of-way. Construct shall also include the act of opening and/or cutting into the surface of any paved or improved surface that is any part of the rights-of-way; Construction means, but shall not be limited to, the act or process of digging, boring, tunneling, trenching, excavating, obstructing, installing or removing signs or facilities, other than landscaping or ornamental plantings, in, on, above, within, over, below, under, or through any part of the rights-of-way. Construction shall also include the act of opening, boring and/or cutting into the surface of any part of the rights-of-way; City manager means the city manager of the city of Decatur, Georgia, or his or her designee; Emergency means a condition that poses a clear and immediate danger to life, health, or safety of a person, or of significant damage to or loss of real or personal property; Facility or facilities means any tangible thing, including but not limited to pipes, mains, conduits, cables, wires, poles, towers, traffic and other signals, and other equipment, appurtenances, appliances and future technology of any utility in, on, along, over, or under any part of the rights-of-way within the city; Facilities representative(s) means the specifically identified agent(s)/employee(s) of a utility who is/are authorized to direct field activities of that utility and serve as official notice agent(s) for facilities related information. Utility shall be required to make sure at least one of its facilities representatives is available at all times to receive notice of, and immediately direct response to, facilities related emergencies or situations; FCC means the Federal Communications Commission or any successor thereto; Rights-of-way means the surface and space in, on, above, within, over, below, under or through any real property in which the city has an interest in law or equity, whether held in fee, or other estate or interest, or as a trustee for the public, including, but not limited to any public street, boulevard, road, highway, freeway, lane, alley, court, sidewalk, parkway, or any other place, area, or real property owned by or under the legal or equitable control of the city, now or hereafter, that consistent with the purposes for which it was dedicated, may be used for the purposes of constructing, operating, repairing or replacing facilities; Service(s) means the offering of any service by a utility for a fee directly to the public, or to such classes of users as to be effectively available directly to the public, or alternatively, the provision of any service by a utility between two or more points for a proprietary purpose to a class of users other than the general public; Service agreement means a valid license agreement, service agreement, franchise, franchise agreement, intergovernmental agreement, or operating and maintenance agreement issued by the city or state pursuant to law and accepted by a utility or entered into by and between the city and a utility, which allows such utility to operate or provide service within the geographic limits of the city; Street or streets means the surface of, as well as the spaces above and below, any and all the streets, alleys, avenues, roads, bridges, tunnels and public places of the city within the corporate limits of the city, as the same now exist or may be hereafter extended or altered, and any location thereon, thereover or thereunder, and any portion thereof; Transfer means the disposal by the utility, directly or indirectly, by gift, assignment, sale, merger, consolidation, or otherwise, of more than 50 percent at one time of the ownership or controlling interest in the facilities, or of more than 50 percent cumulatively over the term of a written approval of registration of such interests to a corporation, partnership, limited partnership, trust, or association, or person or group of persons acting in concert; Unused facilities means facilities located in the rights-of-way which have remained unused for 12 months and for which the utility is unable to provide the city with a plan detailing the procedure by which the utility intends to begin actively using such facilities within the next 12 months, or that it has a potential purchaser or user of the facilities who will be actively using the facilities within the next 12 months, or, that the availability of such facilities is required by the utility to adequately and efficiently operate its facilities; Utility or utilities means all privately, publicly, or cooperatively owned systems for producing, transmitting, or distributing communication, data, information, telecommunication, cable television, video services, power, electricity, light, heat, gas, oil, crude products, water/sewer, steam, fire and police signals, traffic control devices, and street lighting systems, and housing or conduit for any of the foregoing, which directly or indirectly serve the public or any part thereof. The term "Utility" may also be used to refer to the owner, operator, utility, service, contractor or subcontractor, or any agent thereof, of any above-described utility or utility facility. Utility permit means an authorization which grants permission to conduct specific regulated activities on, in, over, under or within any public rights-of-way, and which may be subject to conditions specified in a written agreement with the city or in a related provision of this Code; (Ord. No. O-17-03, § 1, 3-29-17) Sec. 86-173. - Registration required. Each utility that occupies, uses or has facilities in the rights-of-way at the time of passage of this article, including by lease, sublease or assignment, to operate facilities located in the rights-of-way, unless specifically exempted by state or federal law or this Code, shall file a registration statement with the city manager within 90 days of the effective date of this article. (Ord. No. O-17-03, § 1, 3-29-17) Sec. 86-174. - Registration procedure. The registration information provided to the city shall be on a form approved by the city manager, which shall include, but not be limited to: (1) The name, legal status (i.e., partnership, corporation, etc.), street address, email address, and telephone and facsimile numbers of the utility filing the registration statement (the "registrant"). If the registrant is not the owner of the facility in the rights-of-way, the registration shall include the name, street address, email address if applicable, and telephone and facsimile numbers of the owner; (2) The name, street address, email address and telephone and facsimile numbers of one (1) or more facilities representative(s). Current information regarding how to contact the facilities representative(s), in an emergency shall be provided at the time of filing a registration and shall be updated as necessary to assure accurate contact information is available to the city at all times; (3) A copy of the utility's certificate of authority (or other acceptable evidence of authority to operate) from the Georgia Public Service Commission and/or the FCC and any other similar approvals, permits, or agreements. (4) A copy of the service agreement, if applicable or other legal instrument that authorizes the utility to use or occupy the rights-of-way for the purpose described in the registration. (5) A copy of the approved annual work plan required by Section 9.1.8 of Part IV of this Code. (Ord. No. O-17-03, § 1, 3-29-17) Sec. 86-175. - Incomplete registration. If a registration is incomplete, the city manager shall notify the registrant and require that the registration be completed within 14 days of registrant's receipt of such notice. If a registration is complete, the city manager shall so notify the registrant in writing. (Ord. No. O-17-03, § 1, 3-29-17) Sec. 86-176. - Registration acceptance. Acceptance of the registration shall not convey title in the rights-of-way. Acceptance of the registration is only the nonexclusive, limited right to occupy rights-of-way in the city for the limited purposes stated in the acceptance. Acceptance of the registration does not excuse a utility from obtaining permits required by city ordinances nor from obtaining appropriate access or pole attachment agreements before using the facilities of others, including the city. Acceptance of the registration does not excuse a utility from notifying the city of construction as required herein, nor does such acceptance relieve any responsibility for compliance with franchises previously granted by the city or with franchise requirements in Chapter 96 of Part III of this Code. (Ord. No. O-17-03, § 1, 3-29-17) Sec. 86-177. - Facilities in place without registration. Beginning one year after the effective date of this article, any facilities or part of a facility found in a rights-of-way for which registration is required but has not been obtained unless specifically exempted by law, and/or for which no valid service agreement exists with the city, may be deemed to be a nuisance and an unauthorized use of the rights-of-way. The city may exercise any remedies or rights it has at law or in equity, including, but not limited to: abating the nuisance; taking possession of the facilities; evicting the utility from the rights-of-way; prosecuting the violator and/or any other remedy provided by city ordinance. (Ord. No. O-17-03, § 1, 3-29-17) Sec. 86-178. - Permit required. It shall be unlawful for any utility to excavate or to construct, install, maintain, renew, remove or relocate facilities in, on, along, over or under the rights-of-way of the city without a utility permit from the city manager in accordance with the terms of this article. (Ord. No. O-17-03, § 1, 3-29-17) Sec. 86-179. - Permit procedure. Utility permits shall be obtained from the city manager upon application made on forms prescribed by the city manager. The written application shall be accompanied by the following: (1) An indemnity bond or other acceptable security in an amount to be set by the city to pay for any damages to any part of the city road system or other public or private property or to any city employee or member of the public caused by activity or work of the utility performed under authority of the permit issued; (2) A copy, if requested, of the registrant's certificate of authority (or other acceptable evidence of authority to operate) from the Georgia Public Service Commission and/or the FCC and any other similar approvals, permits, or agreements; and (3) A copy, if requested, of the service agreement, if applicable, or other legal instrument that authorizes the utility to use or occupy the rights-of-way for the purpose described in the application. (4) The applicable permit fee. (Ord. No. O-17-03, § 1, 3-29-17) Sec. 86-180. - Permit fees. Fees shall be established by the city commission and set forth in the schedule of fees. (Ord. No. O-17-03, § 1, 3-29-17) Sec. 86-181. - Issuance of permit. If the city manager determines the applicant has satisfied the following requirements, the city manager may issue a utility permit: (1) Whether issuing of the approval will be consistent with this article; and (2) Whether applicant has submitted a complete application and has secured all certificates and other authorizations required by law, if applicable, in order to construct facilities in the manner proposed by the applicant; and (3) Whether the application provides sufficient mitigation of impact on safety, visual quality of the streets, traffic flow, and other users of the rights-of-way and the difficulty and expected length of project construction or maintenance, and (4) Whether the application includes adequate provisions for general public notice and direct notification to parties that will be impacted by issuance of the permit. (Ord. No. O-17-03, § 1, 3-29-17) Sec. 86-182. - Emergency situations. (a) Each utility shall, as soon as reasonably practicable, notify the city manager of any event regarding its facilities which it considers to be an emergency. The utility may proceed to take whatever actions are necessary in order to respond to the emergency. A utility that engages in an emergency excavation shall take all reasonable precautions to avoid or minimize damage to any existing facilities and structures. (b) In the event that the city becomes aware of an emergency regarding utility facilities, the city may attempt to contact the affected utility, through its facilities representative(s). The city may take whatever action it deems necessary in order to respond to the emergency, including cutting or moving any of the wires, cables, amplifiers, appliances, or other parts of the facilities. The city shall not incur any liability to the utility for such emergency actions and the reasonable cost of such work shall be paid by each utility affected by the emergency. (Ord. No. O-17-03, § 1, 3-29-17) Sec. 86-183. - Effective period of permit. (a) Each utility permit shall have set commencement and expiration dates based on information provided in the applicant's permit application. (b) The utility permit shall remain in place until construction is completed or until its expiration date unless the utility is in default. The city manager may give written notice of default to a utility if it is determined that a utility has: (1) Violated any provision or requirement of the issuance or acceptance of a utility permit application or any law of the city, state, or federal government; (2) Attempted to evade any provision or requirement of this article; (3) Engaged in any fraud or deceit upon the city; or (4) Made a material misrepresentation or omission of fact in its permit application. (Ord. No. O-17-03, § 1, 3-29-17) Sec. 86-184. - Cancellation for cause. If a utility fails to cure a default within 20 days of receipt of such notice provided to the utility by the city, then such default shall be a material breach and city may terminate the utility permit. (Ord. No. O-17-03, § 1, 3-29-17) Sec. 86-185. - Expiration of permit. If work is not begun within six months of the date of issuance, the utility permit will automatically expire. (Ord.
